title: 3D Scanning Methods for Reverse Engineering
description: This subject is designed to build on the knowledge and proficiency in the principles and techniques of reverse engineering learnt in the Introduction to Reverse Engineering subject, whilst using 3D scanning methods. Through this subject, students gain experience in using 3D scanning technology to capture a component’s complete geometry and using mesh clean-up tools to prepare faceted bodies for downstream modelling and/or manufacturing. They also learn how to identify logical facet shapes and group triangles for use in the creation of faces, use reverse engineering software to create native surfaces on top of imported data, and use deviation analysis to ensure accuracy between the re-engineered part and its original. This subject equips students with the skills necessary to apply reverse engineering techniques using 3D scanning methods for manufacturing, quality assurance, or other purposes.

title: Additive Manufacturing 1
description: This subject offers a foundational understanding of additive manufacturing, also known as 3D printing, equipping you with the knowledge and skills to transform raw materials into products through this thriving manufacturing method. You will learn about the standardised additive manufacturing processes, develop skills in design and fabrication, and practise the typical workflow required for successful production to prepare you for the evolving 3D printing industry.

title: Advanced Algorithms
description: Algorithms are the heart of computer science and information technology. This subject dives deeply into more advanced data structures and algorithmic techniques for solving problems, particularly graph and optimisation problems.  You will practice implementing these ideas to solve new problems, gain experience testing and evaluating the performance of algorithms, and learn to communicate algorithmic strategies effectively.

title: Advanced Biomedical Engineering Studio A
description: In this advanced studio subject, you'll engage with cutting-edge biomedical engineering research through one of two project streams: Single Cell Sequencing in Cancer or Lateral Flow Assay. The first project equips you with bioinformatics skills to analyse cancer datasets using single-cell sequencing technology. The second offers hands-on experience in creating rapid diagnostic tests, similar to COVID-19 rapid antigen test, involving nanoparticle technology, assay fabrication, SolidWorks and MATLAB data analysis. By the end, you'll have honed project design and problem-solving abilities through both individual and team works, alongside knowledge and technical expertise in these emerging biomedical engineering fields.

title: Advanced Biomedical Engineering Studio B
description: This pre-professional studio subject offers you an in-depth, hands-on experience in the development of innovative medical technologies. You will work in collaborative teams to solve real-world biomedical engineering problems through the design and development of both physical devices and software solutions. Projects may include the prototyping of Point-of-Care PCR diagnostic tools for pathogen detection, as well as the development of AI-driven applications for medical imaging and EEG signal classification. You will engage in 3D CAD design, additive manufacturing, system integration, and experimental testing, while also applying deep learning methods to address challenges in biomedical signal and image analysis. The subject emphasises the development of key pre-professional skills, including technical problem-solving, iterative design, stakeholder analysis, teamwork, and communication of complex technical concepts. By the end of the subject, you will have gained valuable experience in project execution and will be better prepared for professional roles in the biomedical device industry or further applied research.

title: Advanced Engineering Computing
description: This subject aims to enhance your proficiency in advanced computational methods essential for civil engineering, with a focus on developing and analysing mathematical models commonly used in structural engineering. You will also refine your modelling and programming skills through practical use of MATLAB, a widely-used software tool in the field.

title: Advanced Fluid and Particle Mechanics
description:
In this Developing subject, you will be asked to engage in the analysis of complex fluids, which are widely used in modern technologies and industries, particularly in foods, water, printing and coating materials, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and mineral processing. Understanding the fundamental principles of non-Newtonian fluids and particle mechanics in a fluid is crucial in these engineering practices. The subject will equip you with practical knowledge of fluid and particle mechanics in the context of chemical process engineering, where fluid (liquid or gas) interacts with particulate solids.
 
The subject has three parts: it begins by covering rheological concepts of non-Newtonian fluids, such as viscoelasticity, physical properties, and quantities, with an emphasis on the design calculation of the flow. Basic principles of viscometry and analysis of rheological measurements are also introduced. Then, you are invited to investigate how complex fluids are understood within the context of microscopic aspects of surface and interface sciences. This includes surface and interfacial tension, surface chemistry, and their correlation to colloidal stability.  The final section will provide coverage of single and multi-particles in fluid, solid-fluid transport, particle aggregation and agglomeration, and particle transport, slurries and fluid flow through a packed bed of particles are discussed in association with relevant case studies and numerical problem-solving methods using computational calculation.
 
Completion of this subject will enable you to describe and model the physical behaviour of fluid-particle systems and perform design calculations and analyses of typical chemical engineering processes involving non-Newtonian fluids or complex fluid-particle systems.

title: Advanced Games Programming
description: This developing level subject dives into the advanced games topics of artificial intelligence, procedural content generation, and networked multiplayer. You will learn these topics by utilising the industry-standard game engine, Unreal Engine 5, and the C++ programming language. You will learn skills and concepts through assessed weekly lab modules that will teach you skills and algorithms that are transferable between game development environments and that can generalise across many aspects of games development. You will further develop your understanding of these topics and combine them in a session-long group project that will culminate in a novel game or tool prototype that enhances your portfolio and prepares you for significant contributions to third-year capstone projects. The subject's development was supported by the 2019 Epic MegaGrants scheme.

title: Advanced Interaction Design
description: This subject focuses on user experience (UX) in interaction design, crucial for technology adoption and competitive edge. You'll learn conceptual tools to discuss, analyse, and critique UX with digital technologies. The subject covers a range of interactions like mobile, social, pervasive computing, and IoT, helping you understand how to design for specific user experiences in context. You'll also learn design methods like user research, sketching, prototyping, and evaluation to create technology solutions that are not only effective but engaging. By building on fundamental design concepts, you'll be equipped to design technologies that optimise user experience.

title: Advanced Internet Programming
description: In this subject, you'll craft sophisticated web applications ready for production, focusing on server-side programming and business-to-business systems. Topics include web development stacks, n-tier architectures, security, and web-service integration. Emulating a tech startup or software project, you will iteratively refine a prototype, ensuring its security, reliability, and maintainability for real-world customers. Through hands-on labs and group work, you'll enhance your internet programming, problem-solving, and collaborative skills. Additionally, self-directed learning and professional community engagement are expected outside of class.

title: Advanced iOS Development
description: This subject offers an advanced insight into iOS application development with Swift and SwiftUI, where you'll master complex concepts, frameworks, and tools to create robust, innovative iOS apps. It emphasises hands-on experience with industry-standard practices, pushing you to devise solutions that address real-world software needs.

title: Advanced Programming and Use of Collaborative Robots
description: This subject is designed to extend students' knowledge of cobots, focusing on applying cobots to industry relevant tasks. Through this subject, students gain experience programming cobots to perform industry-relevant complex tasks and troubleshoot emergent challenges related to cobots. Students are able to integrate a cobot with peripheral equipment to form part of a larger system, and utilise end-of-arm-tooling to perform physical operations such as materials handing and palletising.

title: Advanced Software Development
description: This subject advances your understanding of software development, such as the design, development, and evaluation of a complex software system that fulfills specific functional and non-functional requirements. You will work in highly autonomous teams that, while supervised and directed, take full responsibility for the project and delivery of the expected outcomes. The subject focuses on professional practices including team management, project planning, and all key software development processes. You will also make and justify informed design decisions, enhancing your capability to deliver sound software solutions.

title: AI/Analytics Capstone Project
description: This subject culminates your data analytics skills through a team-based project that tackles real-world problems in academia or industry. You'll manage investigations, document progress, and communicate findings. The project encompasses data generation, processing, modelling, analysis, and result interpretation. With an academic mentor's support, your performance is evaluated through written reports and an oral presentation, meeting academic and industry standards.

title: AI/Analytics Capstone Project B
description:
In this subject, you'll engage with a project around data analytics or artificial intelligence. You'll initiate this project in a learning contract, guided by a mentor, to either address a research issue through guided semi-independent research or solve a complex real-world problem by applying practical steps -- data preparation, data preprocessing, pattern discovery/model training, evaluation, and application/deployment, culminating in a detailed report of your findings/solution.
This subject equips you with expertise in data analytics/AI techniques and professional communication of results.

title: Application Development in the iOS Environment
description: This subject introduces you to iOS application development, focusing on the Swift programming language and the iOS development environment. You'll gain practical experience with iOS app frameworks through hands-on software development exercises.

title: Application Development using GCP
description: This subject advances your understanding of Cloud Computing, specifically through the Google Cloud Platform (GCP). You'll explore GCP's core services, architecture principles, scaling practices, and Kubernetes usage. The subject prepares you for Google certification with two GCP-based assessments, designed to test your GCP skills, architectural knowledge, and proficiency in Kubernetes.

title: Application Development with .NET
description: This subject introduces you to C# programming using Visual Studio and the .NET development framework. You will explore the .NET framework and its core concepts, applying this knowledge to develop applications in C#.

title: Applications Studio A
description: In this studio, the first in the applications stage for Data and Electronic Engineering majors, you'll transform knowledge into action within a non-traditional, hands-on learning environment. Engage in product-based projects inside the studio, working alongside fellow students, academics, and industry mentors, mixing self-study with collaborative teamwork. Following the engineering cycle—assess, design, implement—you'll apply your knowledge to achieve tangible outcomes, guided by a learning contract set early on. The Applications Studio hones your specialist theoretical understanding and practical skills, focusing on analysis, modelling, benchmarking, and simulation in product development. This studio expects a higher level of proficiency, with students ready to tackle more complex product development tasks, leveraging their advanced knowledge and skills.

title: Applications Studio B
description: In the second studio of the applications stage for Data and Electronic Engineering majors, you'll be immersed in a studio subject that eschews standard curricula in favour of a practical, creative space. Here, you'll convert your existing or new knowledge into practical skills through product-based projects. Collaborating with peers, faculty, and industry experts, you'll navigate the engineering process of assessment, design, and implementation in both solo and team efforts, steered by a learning contract. The Applications Studio deepens your specialist theoretical and practical abilities, with a focus on analysis, modelling, benchmarking, and simulation. You're expected to demonstrate a high proficiency, ready to engage in more complex product development challenges, using advanced knowledge and skills.

title: Applied Mechanics and Design A
description: In this foundational subject, you'll learn how to analyse and design load-bearing mechanical components to meet strength and stiffness requirements. You'll use the methods of engineering mechanics including free-body-diagrams and equations of equilibrium to determine external and internal forces and moments. You’ll use mechanics of materials methods to determine stress, strain and deflection. You'll also conduct laboratory experiments to determine mechanical properties of materials and component behaviour and compare your experimental results with theoretical calculations and published data.

title: Applying Network Security
description: In this subject, you will delve into the theory behind computer security and apply it practically, drawing on content from the Network Security course provided by the Cisco Academy. You'll focus on network security appliances and infrastructure, including firewalls, access control, secure network design, Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), and data encryption, to build a robust understanding of protecting digital networks.

title: Architecting on AWS
description: This subject hones your skills in engineering and deploying enterprise-grade applications in the cloud, specifically using AWS. By the end of the subject, you will have acquired the knowledge and skills necessary to become an AWS Certified Solutions Architect (Associate), as the curriculum aligns with the authorized AWS Academy content.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Robotics
description: This subject delves into Artificial Intelligence (AI) concepts, theory, and algorithms relevant to robotics and mechatronic systems, covering data-driven perception, and various machine learning paradigms applied to intelligent robots including traditional, reinforcement and deep learning. Through workshops and tutorials, you will grasp the technical and ethical complexities of intelligent systems, learning to identify and apply cutting-edge algorithms and tools for autonomous decision-making. This knowledge is essential as intelligent robots increasingly reshape industries and society.

title: Automation Studio
description:
This studio-based subject is a hands-on, project-based subject that introduces the principles and technologies of modern industrial automation. You will explore how industrial sensors, actuators, controllers, and communication systems work together to automate complex processes in fields such as manufacturing, energy, transport, and smart infrastructure. The subject focuses on practical design and implementation, using tools such as programmable logic controllers (PLCs), human-machine interfaces (HMIs), real-time monitoring, and control systems. You will learn how to program, integrate, and test automated process, while developing critical skills in system design, fault diagnosis, and process optimisation. Through workshops and studio activities, you will work collaboratively to build and validate complete automation solutions. These hands-on projects provide experience in translating engineering concepts into real-world applications, while also considering key challenges such as safety, scalability, and sustainability.
By the end of the subject, you will be able to design and deploy intelligent automation systems that respond dynamically to real-time inputs. You will understand how automation supports innovation in Industry 4.0 and prepares the foundation for advanced work in control, robotics, and cyber-physical systems. Therefore, Automation Studio equips you with practical skills and creative confidence to take on engineering challenges in a rapidly evolving technological landscape.

title: AWS Industry Studio
description: This studio subject centres on practical application development with AWS, aiming to foster professional competence through a practice-based learning environment for students pursuing an AWS Industry sub-major. You'll engage with reflective design practice, teamwork, mentoring, and deep learning techniques, including architecting and scaling with AWS infrastructure.

title: Biomedical Industry Frameworks
description: This subject will provide you with an understanding of the regulatory frameworks and procedures in the biotech and medical device industry. You will learn to navigate quality systems, management systems, regulatory affairs, design processes, ethics, IP and risk analysis such as FMEAs, applying relevant tools in medical device regulation. You will also become familiar with regulatory environments in Australia and other international markets such as the US and EU. This knowledge will lay the groundwork for a career within the medical device regulatory area.

title: Business Intelligence
description: This undergraduate subject equips you with an understanding of business intelligence applications in organisational contexts, focusing on knowledge management, business process management, and decision-making. By taking this subject, you will gain valuable skills in generating, sharing, retaining, and applying information and knowledge within corporations, which are crucial for enhancing business efficiency and decision-making processes. You will develop essential skills in system development approaches and design strategies for business intelligence systems, preparing you for roles in business analysis and system design. These skills will not only help you become proficient in managing business processes but also make you an asset in any organisational setting that relies on data-driven decision-making. Your learning experience will be interactive and practical. Through engaging in case studies, project-based tasks, and group activities, you will apply theoretical knowledge to real-world business issues using different analytical tools. As you handle data sets, you'll improve your skills in analysing and implementing solutions. This practical approach ensures that you not only grasp the theoretical concepts but also become proficient in using these tools to effectively address and resolve business challenges.

title: Business Process and IT Strategy
description:
This subject introduces you to the strategic use of information technology (IT) to enhance business processes and strategies. A major concern for businesses is finding a competitive advantage and effectively leveraging IT resources to align with business goals. For IT managers, this involves understanding and managing complex issues related to the roles of IT and IT strategy in enabling business processes and generating business benefits and competitive advantage. In this subject, we will explore theories and methods related to the value of IT. You will learn about and discuss business and strategy processes that lead to learning organisations capable of achieving sustainable competitive advantage.

Business processes and IT strategy are crucial concerns for both business and IT managers. Managing information is a critical skill for success in today's business environment. Managers need to understand their organisation's capabilities and the use of information resources. This subject aims to provide a foundation to help general business managers become knowledgeable participants in decision-making processes related to information systems (IS). By critically reviewing the contributions of IS resources in businesses and organisational settings, you will gain a contextual understanding of how IS permeates many aspects of business.

Through case studies, this subject reinforces material provided in lectures and tutorials, along with additional research and prior knowledge. It gives you the opportunity to enhance your problem-solving, critical thinking, and organisational skills as part of a group, as well as to engage in peer learning. The subject emphasises the development and assessment of real-world experience through applied and innovative tasks and team effort. You will develop the knowledge and skills required for using and managing information within an organisation, as well as essential management and communication skills.

title: Business Requirements Modelling
description:
This subject focuses on modelling business requirements, emphasising the importance of understanding different perspectives of the users to enhances system quality in resolving real-world business problems. 
You'll explore contemporary requirements modelling approaches, both agile and non-agile software engineering principles, methods, tools, and techniques, to analyse business processes and model requirements via the business process models and data models as well as capture functional and non-functional requirements via agile artifacts and object-oriented models.
You'll participate in interactive and hands-on lectures, tutorials as well as team projects with real-world business problems, which will develop key skills for critical roles like Business Analyst in designing and developing innovative software systems in professional settings

title: Capstone Project
description: This capstone project subject involves executing and documenting your final project. Prior to starting, review 41029 Engineering Research Preparation to understand the prerequisites for this phase of work.

title: Career Management for IT Professionals
description: This subject equips you with the skills and knowledge to excel in initial IT roles, enhancing your employability and professional conduct. You'll learn to craft compelling job applications, excel in interviews, and navigate Australian workplace culture, including effective time management and wellbeing. Active learning is central, with a flipped classroom approach requiring pre-class preparation, enabling in-class discussions and practical exercises on job-seeking and workplace integration. Group projects from Week 4 foster teamwork and project management skills. Additionally, you'll refine your academic and professional language, with milestone tasks gauging your progress in these areas and subject-specific objectives.

title: Chemical Thermodynamics and Reactor Design
description: This subject will provide you with working knowledge to design reactors of common types including plug flow, packedbed, batch and continuously stirred tank reactors. Fundamental knowledge of reaction kinetics and equilibrium is integrated with gas, liquid and solid-state functions (i.e. internal energy, enthalpy, entropy, and Gibbs free energy) to describe and model chemical processes within each reactor type. Design equations are initially formulated with a single chemical reaction then generalised to multiple reactions to illustrate practical reactor design involving chemical, biochemical and catalytic reactions.

title: Circuit Analysis and Design
description: This subject deepens your understanding of the fundamental concepts of circuit analysis, with a particular focus on frequency domain techniques. You'll engage in both theoretical and computer-aided circuit design and validate circuit behaviour through lab experiments and simulation software. Building on your prior knowledge gained on basic circuit elements/devices and circuit analysis skills, the subject introduces theoretical models for signals and systems analysis. Key topics include sinusoidal steady-state analysis with phasor transformation, circuit modelling with differential equations and their solution via Laplace transforms, power in single and three-phase AC circuits, Transfer functions, Bode plots, system responses to various inputs, frequency selective circuits, Fourier series; and two-port network theory. You'll use tools like MATLAB for analytical modelling and simulation, with a strong emphasis on correlating experimental data with theoretical predictions during lab sessions.

title: Civil Engineering Integrated Design Studio
description: In this Pre-Professional studio you will participate in a multidisciplinary project that draws on the various design aspects of Civil and Environmental Engineering, such as structural, geotechnical, environmental and construction aspects. You will explore and integrate various civil engineering related disciplines, highlighting the importance of a cohesive approach to solving complex problems. You will need to draw on and critically incorporate the ways non-technical factors influence engineering outcomes in technical engineering designs including through social, cultural, ethical, legal, political, environmental, and economic contexts. By the end of the subject, you will have developed a comprehensive appreciation of the multifaceted nature of civil engineering projects and their impact on communities and the environment.

title: Cloud Computing and Software as a Service
description: This subject introduces you to cloud computing, covering cloud architecture, IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, virtualisation, and multi-tenancy. You'll engage in group work to produce a research report critically analysing a cloud computing aspect, followed by developing cloud-based software engineering skills on an existing platform. The second assignment involves group collaboration to create a cloud-based software application.

title: Cloud Computing Infrastructure
description: This subject expands on cloud computing, focusing on the setup and operation of cloud infrastructure. You'll explore cloud architecture, virtualisation, storage technologies, data centre basics, and cloud security and compliance. With strong industry relevance, the subject includes practical labs utilising tools prevalent in the cloud infrastructure sector.

title: Collaboration in Complex Projects
description:
This subject immerses you in the sustainable practices of Australia's Indigenous peoples, reflecting their sophisticated engineering principles. You'll undertake a group design project, integrating Indigenous approaches to sustainability and environmental stewardship, thereby deepening your understanding of the Indigenous Graduate Attribute. 

As a culmination of core subjects, you're expected to employ and exhibit advanced teamwork and sustainability skills, as well as your growing Indigenous Professional Capability. Building on previous teamwork experiences, you'll apply collaborative skills to a complex project, working respectfully in diverse teams. Your sustainability comprehension will also be elevated beyond earlier coursework.

Learning occurs through weekly tutorials, where you'll work in groups to create design solutions, including prototypes, for a complex engineering project with Indigenous stakeholder considerations.

The subject adopts a studio format, starting with structured activities and research to ensure clarity on project objectives. Subsequently, you'll independently manage and execute the project, providing weekly progress updates.

Assessments will evaluate your application of respectful communication in both verbal and written forms, demonstrating your engagement with the subject's core values.

title: Collaborative Business Processes
description: This subject provides you with a comprehensive problem-solving framework, essential for agile teams to foster creativity, critical thinking, and innovation. Starting with problem scoping, you'll gain a data-supported understanding of issues, utilising collaborative tools for knowledge sharing. You'll apply techniques like process modelling and systems thinking to generate solutions, while focusing on addressing current and emergent societal or business challenges. The subject encourages knowledge exchange and the development of practical solutions.

title: Collaborative Robotics Studio
description: This subject on collaborative robotics (cobots) expands your understanding of how robots can work alongside humans in various industries. In a studio setting, you will learn to program cobots, both through scripting and hands-on interaction, building on your prior knowledge of robotics and automation. This experience utilising cobot technology prepares you to innovate in fields where human-robot collaboration currently is or will be a key component.

title: Communication for IT Professionals
description:
This core subject will highlight new ways of working, provide insights into the scope of technology, and look at considerations within the Australian context. You will learn to make decisions that impact people, community, and the environment. Through authentic experiences, you will develop skills and knowledge, providing a solid base for your continuous professional development as an IT professional.

In the subject, you will complete the Engineers Without Borders Challenge, working in a team to develop solutions to real-world challenges for an Australian Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island community. You will form a team with peers, working in and outside class throughout the session on the project that you select. Your team will research the project background, refine scope and identify technological considerations. You will then ideate and prototype potential solutions that work in the community context. Finally, you will propose a fully developed design idea that benefits the partner community.

In completing the challenge, you will develop multidisciplinary and professional skills including:  researching skills to inform the development of design solutions;
applying the design process to solve genuine humanitarian challenges; considering socio-technical issues including working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities; developing professional communications skill; and participating and leading team processes.

title: Communication for IT Professionals
description: This core subject will highlight new ways of working and provide insights into the scope of technology. You will learn to make decisions that impact people, community, and the environment. Through an authentic challenge, you will develop skills and knowledge, providing a solid base for your continuous professional development as an IT professional. In the subject, you will complete a set real-world challenge, working in a team to develop solutions. You will form a team with peers, working in and outside class throughout the session on the project that you select. Your team will research the project background, refine scope and identify technological considerations. You will then ideate and prototype potential solutions that work in a community context. Finally, you will propose a fully developed design idea that benefits the identified community. In completing the challenge, you will develop multidisciplinary and professional skills including research skills to inform the development of design solutions; applying the design process to solve genuine humanitarian challenges; considering socio-technical issues; developing professional communication skills; and participating and leading team processes.

title: Computer Graphics
description: This subject equips you with problem-solving and communication skills specific to computer graphics, focusing on shape representation, manipulation, and visualisation. You will learn to design and implement 3D interactive graphics for applications such as virtual reality (VR), data visualisation, and gaming. Balancing theory and practice, you'll delve into graphical pipelines and representations and apply this knowledge using WebGL and the ThreeJS framework. You'll emerge with an understanding of the systems driving game engines and 3D animation software and the ability to create interactive 3D web applications, valuable for various studies and careers.

title: Computer Modelling and Design
description: This subject equips senior civil engineering students with the skills to create and analyse computer models of load-bearing structures. You'll learn to determine building loads in line with Australian standards and apply them to your models. The subject builds on previous structural design studies, introducing you to commercial structural analysis software through practical lab sessions.

title: Computing Science Learning Integrated Work A
description: This subject bridges the gap between traditional academic study and practical, workplace experience. By scaffolding learning occurring in the workplace, you will develop your discipline skills, reflective practice and professional capabilities.  With the support of a workplace mentor, you will further develop your understanding of your own professional development and your ability to communicate both your achievement and your development in a professional context.

title: Computing Science Learning Integrated Work B
description: This subject bridges the gap between traditional academic study and practical, workplace experience. By scaffolding learning occurring in the workplace, you will develop your discipline skills, reflective practice and professional capabilities. With the support of a workplace mentor, you will further develop your understanding of your own professional development and your ability to communicate both your achievement and your development in a professional context.

title: Computing Science Learning Integrated Work C
description: This subject bridges the gap between traditional academic study and practical, workplace experience. By scaffolding learning occurring in the workplace, you will develop your discipline skills, reflective practice and professional capabilities. With the support of a workplace mentor, you will further develop your understanding of your own professional development and your ability to communicate both your achievement and your development in a professional context.

title: Computing Science Learning Integrated Work D
description: This subject bridges the gap between traditional academic study and practical, workplace experience. By scaffolding learning occurring in the workplace, you will develop your discipline skills, reflective practice and professional capabilities. With the support of a workplace mentor, you will further develop your understanding of your own professional development and your ability to communicate both your achievement and your development in a professional context.

title: Computing Science Studio 1
description: This subject immerses you in the world of computer science research, examining its purpose and methodologies. You will develop academic writing skills for literature reviews and reports, explore research collaboration, leadership, and ethics, and under mentor guidance, investigate chosen topics. There's encouragement to consult with leading computer scientists and a focus on honing communication, ethical, and analytical skills vital for a career in computing science.

title: Computing Science Studio 2
description: In this studio-based subject, you will apply your prior knowledge and cutting-edge research advances to solve real-world problems, often requiring cross-disciplinary solutions. From conceptualisation to execution, you will work in a team to develop and deliver a small project, guided by UTS's leading researchers. This experience will enhance your problem-solving skills, refine your communication skills, strengthen your grasp of professional ethics, and enhance your analytical abilities for critical literature evaluation, as a stepping stone for the research component in your computing science course. This subject builds upon the groundwork laid in Computing Science Studio 1.

title: Concrete Design
description: This subject advances your understanding of reinforced concrete (RC) and prestressed concrete (PSC) structures, essential for civil engineers in Australia. Building on prior knowledge of statics, solid mechanics, and structural analysis, you'll learn about the design and behaviour of RC beams, slabs, and columns, as well as PSC beams, focusing on both serviceability and strength. The subject introduces the Limit State Design philosophy of AS3600-2018 and material properties of concrete, steel reinforcement, and prestressing steel. You'll study both uncracked and cracked beam cross-section analysis, RC beam design for serviceability, bending, and shear, and explore ductility in various beam types. The subject also covers the analysis and design of one-way and two-way slabs, columns, reinforcement detailing, and an introduction to PSC beam design, including history, section analysis, load-balancing, and design for bending in determinate structures.

title: Construction
description: This subject introduces you to the construction industry, focusing on the technical, managerial, and collaborative skills essential for professionals in the field. You'll explore innovative management theories, concepts, and tools, and critically analyse and solve construction management issues. The subject also fosters teamwork skills crucial for the collaborative execution of construction projects.

title: Construction Materials
description: In this subject, you will learn about the engineering properties of construction materials and how to predict their behaviour in practical applications. This includes examining the composition of steel and concrete, with detailed analysis of the properties of various components, including cement, aggregates, and admixtures. You will gather experimental data using Australian Standard test methods to understand material properties and behaviours. This knowledge is then applied to design materials that meet specifications, sustainability, and service life criteria, considering environmental effects and failure modes. You will develop professional problem-solving and design skills, enabling you to select suitable materials for prescriptive and performance-based requirements and to justify your choices. The subject will also enhance your analytical and reflective skills for construction material analysis, design, and development.

title: Control Design
description: This electrical and electronic engineering common core subject provides a comprehensive introduction to principles and techniques used in the analysis and design of control systems. You will explore topics such as mathematical modelling, stability analysis, and feedback control. You will gain practical experience through demonstrations and simulations, while preparing you for more advanced project work in control systems. By the end of the subject, you will be able to transform a manual plant into an autonomous system by designing stable control strategies with guaranteed closed-loop dynamic performance. After completing this subject, you will be able to apply this knowledge to engineering challenges in areas such as Industry 4.0, robotics, automation, renewable energy integration, electric vehicles, and all kinds of electromechanical systems.

title: Cryptography
description: In this subject, you will delve into the critical role of cryptographic techniques in maintaining data confidentiality and ensuring data integrity. These techniques are foundational in cybersecurity, securing a variety of systems such as wireless networks, online payment systems, and cryptocurrencies. You will explore key principles of cryptography, including both symmetric and asymmetric ciphers, cryptographic hash functions, message authentication codes, and digital signatures. Additionally, this subject introduces you to the popular applications of cryptography, such as the cryptographic designs in blockchain. Through hands-on exercises, you will analyse various cryptographic techniques, use popular cryptographic tools, and practise simulated attacks on cryptographic systems.

title: Cybersecurity
description: This subject equips you with vital cybersecurity skills, addressing the dual aspects of people management and technology to mitigate risks like legal repercussions, financial losses, and eroded trust. You'll develop a robust understanding of cyber-attacks, defense mechanisms, and security services—confidentiality, integrity, availability. You'll also gain hands-on experience with industry-standard technologies such as IPSec, SSL, PGP, and S/MIME. Through practical application, you'll be prepared to enhance the cybersecurity posture of contemporary organisations.

title: Cybersecurity Capstone Studio
description:
In this pre-professional capstone subject, you will work in teams in a studio environment to analyse, design and implement secure projects, integrating skills and knowledge acquired in other subjects throughout the subject. The capstone project provides you with an opportunity to engage with current industry challenges in cybersecurity and design and prototype solutions.

You will analyse project requirements, evaluate design decisions, and explore innovative products, technologies, or opportunities. Assessment focuses on technical capability as well as essential professional skills like communication, project management, leadership, and teamwork, demonstrated through project artefacts you develop during the capstone. Although the capstone is team-based, you will individually record your progress and contributions, as well as reflect on your learning and professional development as a cybersecurity professional.

title: Data Analytics in Cybersecurity
description: Data Analytics for Cybersecurity equips you with the skills to leverage big data and threat intelligence in combating both insider and external cyber threats. You will learn to apply statistical methods to discern patterns and use intelligent technologies to identify security issues from data. The subject introduces machine learning applications in cybersecurity and standard data analytics processes. Through hands-on exercises, you will develop practical skills in analysing corporate computer and network vulnerabilities, thereby enhancing your ability to identify and mitigate security risks. This subject bridges the gap between data analytics and cybersecurity, providing you with the tools to effectively protect modern digital infrastructures.

title: Data Driven and Intelligent Robotics
description: This subject equips you to develop intelligent robot behaviours, distinct from traditional business applications. Working in teams on real-world problems, you'll hone your skills in data analytics and machine learning, appreciate the complexities and ethical considerations of real-time, data-driven systems, and learn to select advanced algorithms and tools. Completing this subject prepares you to contribute significantly to teams creating intelligent systems that will reshape business and society.

title: Data Structures and Algorithms
description: This subject equips you with the skills to design, evaluate, and implement data structures and algorithms using C++, ensuring they meet criteria for functionality and usability. You'll learn the underlying concepts, theories, and technologies essential for creating software solutions that are suitable, understandable, easy to learn, and compliant.

title: Data Systems
description: This subject delves into systems engineering for complex, data-centric systems, covering their lifecycle from design to management. You'll learn to build data pipelines through Extract, Transform, Load processes, apply Python for data engineering and reporting, and explore the Hadoop ecosystem and cloud data system providers. The learning experience is project-based, combining workshops on data engineering with collaborative project work, equipping you with practical, in-demand skills.

title: Database Fundamentals
description:
This subject lays the foundation for effective database systems, teaching you how data is structured and managed within organizations, ensuring its usability for applications and users. You will also learn SQL for effective data retrieval and modification, enhancing your ability to work with databases in various contexts.
 
During the subject, you'll explore the significance and challenges of good database design and management, which underpin a strong basis for developing functional software applications. You'll enhance your skills through hands-on practicals and case study analyses, applying theoretical concepts to real-world situations.
 
This subject is particularly beneficial for students pursuing majors in computer science, information systems, or related fields. It prepares you for roles in database administration, software development, and data analysis.

title: Database Principles
description: This subject provides a foundational understanding of database design and implementation, focusing on relational design principles and Entity Relationship Diagrams. You will learn to interpret and develop these diagrams and access databases using Structured Query Language (SQL) for data retrieval. Additionally, the subject covers the coding skills necessary to construct a database. Preparation is essential ahead of lectures, while labs offer practical exercises for your learning, ensuring you can effectively design and query databases.

title: Database Programming
description: This subject instructs you on crafting database programming and administration solutions with Oracle 11G, SQL*Plus, and PL/SQL, ensuring they adhere to quality characteristics such as suitability, security, operability, efficiency, and maintainability. You'll delve into the relevant concepts, theories, and technologies while applying your knowledge to develop an application that addresses a specific database issue.

title: Designing Sustainable Engineering Projects
description:
In this subject, you'll advance from foundational design principles to completing a full design cycle, from problem identification to presenting solutions to a client, incorporating systems thinking. Sustainability is central, encompassing environmental, economic, and social aspects, and you'll apply relevant tools and techniques within a group project themed by the coordinator, such as food or energy security.

You'll work in teams, rotating roles to explore different sustainability perspectives, integrating feedback to refine your approach. Researching individually and in team, you'll converge to select appropriate sustainability frameworks and design a solution mindful of various factors, culminating in a professionally framed report.

title: Digital Forensics
description: In this practice-based subject, you will engage in laboratory-based learning to determine if a crime has been committed through the acquisition, analysis, and reporting of digital evidence. Your studies will focus on forensic analysis of network data, including the recovery of website visitation evidence relevant for court cases, alongside scrutinising digital storage devices to identify and retrieve critical data. You will also delve into the examination of operating systems to unearth hidden data, perform detailed analysis of metadata to gain deeper insights, and apply rigorous forensic principles to produce sound and defensible reports. Through these hands-on activities, you will develop a comprehensive understanding of digital forensics and its applications in real-world scenarios.

title: Directed Study 1
description: This subject offers you the chance to co-design learning experiences with a supervisor, tailored to your interests. You can engage in student-led or vocational projects, work integrated learning (WIL), research placements, or activity-based experiences like competitions, workshops, community service, or advanced study under mentorship.

title: Directed Study 2
description: This subject offers you the opportunity to co-design learning experiences with a supervisor, tailored to your interests. You can engage in student-led or vocational projects, work integrated learning (WIL), research placements, or activity-based experiences like competitions, workshops, community service, or advanced study under mentorship.

title: Directed Study 3
description: This subject offers you the opportunity to co-design learning experiences with a supervisor, tailored to your interests. You can engage in student-led or vocational projects, work integrated learning (WIL), research placements, or activity-based experiences like competitions, workshops, community service, or advanced study under mentorship.

title: Directed Study 4
description: This subject offers you the opportunity to co-design learning experiences with a supervisor, tailored to your interests. You can engage in student-led or vocational projects, work integrated learning (WIL), research placements, or activity-based experiences like competitions, workshops, community service, or advanced study under mentorship.

title: Dynamic Systems and Control A
description: This subject focuses on the critical role of vibration and noise control in the design, performance, and longevity of mechanical and structural systems. You'll learn to model simplified linear dynamic systems common in mechanical and mechatronic engineering and analyse their vibration behaviours subject to various inputs. You’ll also learn classical control engineering techniques to manipulate the dynamics of mechanical and mechatronic systems for desired outcomes. The concepts and tools covered are applicable across various engineering disciplines.

title: Economics and Finance for Engineering Projects
description: This subject enhances your financial and economic literacy in the context of engineering projects. You'll learn to assess costs and benefits of an engineering project using techniques like cash flow, valuation, and costing. Additionally, you will develop competence in the financial language in the engineering domain by analysing financial reports and assessing the impacts of engineering projects on the financial performance of a business.

title: Electrical Machines
description: This subject introduces you to contemporary electrical machines and drives, covering their technology, applications, and the use of Matlab/Simulink for modelling. You will study transformers, electrical drives, and various machines including DC, synchronous, induction, and switched reluctance machines, with a focus on variable speed drives and energy efficiency. The subject blends lectures, tutorials, and labs, where you will measure machine parameters and performance. Additionally, you will complete four assignments on numerical simulations of machines and drive systems, supported by lecturers and tutors.

title: Electrical Power Systems
description: This subject equips you with methods for analysing and designing electric power networks, building on previous circuit analysis knowledge. You'll gain practical understanding of contemporary power system theory and its application to real-world problems.

title: Electrification and Renewables Studio
description: This is a Developing studio subject in renewable energy engineering where you synthesise your disciplinary knowledge and practice to a unstructured problem or project. Electrification is widely employed in modern transportation, homes, buildings, industry, and agriculture sectors. It offers enhanced energy efficiency, lower maintenance costs, longer lifetimes, and advanced features that significantly improve work performance. The combination of electrification and renewables provides a sustainable solution for reducing carbon footprints and paving the way towards a cleaner energy future. In this subject, you will apply a broad range of technologies and knowledge related to energy system electrification, with a focus on fostering a cleaner energy future. It covers power electronics, electric machines, energy storage systems, renewable energy, and smart grid technologies. By participating in team projects, you will address fundamental issues like analysing power distribution systems, designing efficient power converters, developing innovative energy storage solutions, modelling renewable energy generation and optimising complex electrical systems by using computer simulations. This subject broadens your understanding of electrification technologies but also provides exposure to industry scenarios and aims to enhance your professional skills while contributing to advancements in electrification and renewable energy, ultimately shaping a sustainable future.

title: Electromechanical Automation
description: This subject aims to solidify your understanding of electromagnetic field and circuits as well as the interchange of electric, magnetic, and electromagnetic energy. You will learn about the electromechanical energy conversion, and operation principles of typical electric motors. You will also learn to model electromechanical automation systems using electric motors, simulate their performance, and design closed-loop controllers. You will be able to handle mains voltage equipment, power instrumentation, PLCs, measure motor characteristics, and improve your practical skills. You are expected to achieve levels of knowledge ranging from essential problem-solving and awareness of modern automation systems. A key component is the development of laboratory skills, including electrical safety, accurate measurements, design validation, and experimental verification.

title: Electronic Components and Fabrication
description: This subject focuses on the hardware and components at the heart of the Internet of Things (IoT), with emphasis on miniaturisation and nanotechnology. You will delve into existing miniaturised technologies to understand their capabilities and constraints. This will enable you to design innovative IoT systems and anticipate technological breakthroughs. You will learn about various electronic and photonic components in miniaturised systems, the underlying semiconductor physics and technologies, and appreciate the fabrication and packaging of devices. By mastering the trade-offs between performance, quality, and reliability, you will be able to select appropriate component classes and approaches for creating miniaturised systems tailored to real-world problems.

title: Electronics and Circuits
description: The aim of this subject is to acquaint you with basic electronic circuits, particularly those using operational amplifiers (op-amps), and their practical applications. By the end, you should be adept at analysing basic circuits and constructing and testing them in a lab setting. The subject strongly focuses on hands-on learning to build a robust understanding of analog electronic circuits with op-amps. Lab work, which forms a substantial part of the subject, enhances your skills in circuit construction, testing, and troubleshooting, and familiarises you with test instruments. Additionally, the subject demonstrates the relevance of practical electronic applications across various engineering and technical fields and their broader societal and commercial significance.

title: Embedded Mechatronics Studio
description: In this studio, you'll advance your engineering design skills by creating an analog printed circuit board (PCB) that interfaces with an embedded system, sensors, and actuators to implement a sophisticated and intelligent device. You'll integrate knowledge from earlier studies, applying it to electronics and embedded system programming, gaining practical experience in electronic system design. The focus is on analog circuit design with elements from mechanical design and embedded programming, that is, the studio covers the three main pillars of any mechatronic system. By employing modern Electrical Computer-Aided Design (ECAD), you will learn about sensor signal conditioning, amplification, filtering, analog switching, generating haptic and visual inputs/outputs, and analog-to-digital conversion. Working in groups, you'll address a defined problem with a mechatronic solution and as such, success hinges on effective teamwork, clear communication, and thorough documentation of your design process and rationale.

title: Embedded Mechatronics Systems
description: Embedded Systems are essential for Physical Computing, which involves interactive, often distributed systems that sense and respond to their environment. You'll learn about digital and programmable electronic circuits, small computer systems' hardware architecture, and low-level programming for embedded software. Topics include digital sequential circuits, state diagrams, hardware-software interplay, CPU architecture, memory subsystems, computer system buses, and input/output devices. Additionally, you'll study micro-controller theory, hardware interfacing design, real-time programming basics, and connect MEMS microphones, accelerometers, and other sensors.

title: Embedded Systems Studio A
description: This studio delves into the analysis, design, and implementation of an advanced computing node, focusing on digital hardware at the medium-scale system level. It builds upon introductory digital systems knowledge, employing studio-based learning that covers the digital design process, functional design, implementation technologies, advanced digital architectures, and memory and I/O systems within project work. Post completion, you'll be adept at planning, designing, and developing digital intellectual property (IP) using FPGAs and hardware description languages (HDLs) such as Verilog and VHDL.

title: Embedded Systems Studio B
description: This studio offers a practical experience in designing, constructing, and assessing an embedded system using a microcontroller. You'll progress from the initial concept to a functional product, meeting weekly goals. The subject encourages self-directed learning to gain both theoretical knowledge and practical skills necessary for a comprehensive understanding of microcontroller-based embedded system design, which is pivotal in consumer, industrial, automotive, medical sectors, and the Internet of Things.

title: Emerging Topics in Cybersecurity and Privacy
description: This subject delves into contemporary IT security theories and practical skills in the cybersecurity profession, enhanced by guest lectures and workshops. You will develop a professional understanding of cybersecurity by examining emerging threats to web applications and systems, along with cutting-edge privacy and ethical issues. You'll explore current trends and challenges through professional practice and literature review. Working in small teams, you'll apply modern techniques for requirements elicitation, analysis, modelling, specification, and validation to real-world projects.

title: Emerging Topics in Quantum Information Science
description: In this subject you will delve into the forefront of quantum computing and information science, guided by guest lectures and workshops. This subject equips you with advanced insights into industry-leading research, breakthroughs, and techniques in quantum information sciences. By examining professional practices and research literature, you'll confront current trends and challenges in the field. Through workshops and team discussions, you'll learn to apply best practices in quantum computing analysis, modelling, and experimental methods.

title: Engineering Capstone
description: This subject advances your capstone project, focusing on execution and documentation. It builds on 'Engineering Research Preparation', ensuring you're ready for this critical stage. You'll refine your research and design skills, working independently under an academic supervisor's guidance. Your learning will be hands-on, with scheduled meetings to support your progress.

title: Engineering Computations
description: This subject provides engineering students with the opportunity to acquire knowledge of numerical methods, programming, and engineering software and to apply this knowledge in engineering problem solving. Excel spreadsheeting and Matlab programming is required to solve numerical problems in this subject with no prior knowledge of programming being assumed. There are opportunities to apply acquired skills through the assessment of project-based problem solving in the civil and mechanical engineering disciplines. Examples are chosen from within a broader engineering context and serve to reinforce material covered in other subjects in civil and mechanical engineering.

title: Engineering Experience 1
description: This zero-credit subject facilitates your engineering practice experience in industry or community settings, allowing you to immerse in workplace culture and develop technical and professional skills through practice and reflection. Recognising the importance of practical experience alongside academic study, this program encourages you to be an active learner, seeking opportunities to achieve the module's objectives. Your experience will be distinct, with no formal training requirement from hosts. This subject is the practical phase of the first cycle in the Professional Program, involving observation, practice, and reflection to build foundational competencies, and should be undertaken early in your academic journey.

title: Engineering Experience 2
description: This non-credit subject supports you during industry or community work placements, enhancing your practical engineering experience. As an advanced student, you'll work alongside professionals to deepen your understanding of engineering practice and refine your technical skills. Prior to starting, you must enrol in Engineering Practice Preview 2. Your experience will be unique, with no formal training required from hosts, but an expectation for you to proactively learn and meet the objectives of this module. Your learning is complemented by core engineering subjects and the subsequent Engineering Practice Review subject.

title: Engineering Mechanics
description: This subject helps students grasp the fundamental concepts of static equilibrium, crucial for the analysis and design of engineered structures. You'll learn to analyse simple, statically determinate beams and trusses under different loads and supports. By the end of the subject, you'll be adept at applying static equilibrium conditions to analyse structures and appreciate civil engineering design. These principles underpin further studies in structural analysis and design and introduce you to dynamics in civil engineering, including fluid mechanics, hydraulics, and road design.

title: Engineering Project Appraisal
description:
This foundational subject introduces you to key professional engineering frameworks, focusing on ethics, project management, sustainability, and economics. Through this subject, you'll evaluate real-world projects, scrutinising their sustainability and community impact. Building on skills from 'Introduction to Engineering Projects', you'll deepen your understanding of professional practice before tackling more complex projects in subsequent subjects.  
 
The subject applies case studies to link theory to practice. Tutorial sessions foster your collaboration in practicing case study analysis techniques, understanding frameworks, and appraising engineering projects. With peer feedback, you will critique peers' work, honing diverse appraisal approaches.

title: Engineering Project Management
description: In this subject you will learn about the most common frameworks, processes, techniques that are essential in managing engineering projects. It involves entire project lifecycle from project initiation to project closure. You will get to practice project management knowledge from an integrated perspective of scope, time and cost management. In the scope management component, topics including scope definition and control will be introduced. For the time management component, this subject includes the definition of project activities, estimating the duration and resources of activities, developing and controlling project schedule, as well as the planning of project resources. In the cost management component, you will learn about cost estimation and management and control of the project budget. Students work independently and in small groups on a range of assessment tasks.

title: Engineering Research Preparation
description: This subject equips you with the skills to apply engineering knowledge and problem-solving in a capstone project, essential for your final year. You'll tackle complex engineering challenges relevant to industry, academia, or personal interests, developing expertise in research design, project management, and critical communication. Learning involves creating a theoretical framework and project plan, preparing you for the subsequent implementation phase. You'll engage in interactive workshops, focusing on topics like the social perspectives of engineering, research questions, literature reviews, methodologies, ethics. Resources on Canvas and the Reading List support your preparation, while regular meetings with your Capstone Supervisor and peer review seminars enhance your project's development and your ability to critique and improve work collaboratively. This subject hones your application of knowledge and research skills, aligning with Engineers Australia competencies and Australian Qualifications Framework standards for bachelor's and honours degrees.

title: Entrepreneurship and Commercialisation
description: This subject equips you with an understanding of innovation, commercialisation, technology life cycles, and change in engineering and technology. It prepares you for the commercial world by developing your understanding of different roles within an enterprise through a business planning framework. Covering strategy, marketing, operations, personnel, and finance, it offers a practical orientation with contemporary case studies to illustrate concept application. As you approach the end of your undergraduate studies, this knowledge will enable you to communicate effectively with various organisational functions.

title: Environmental and Sanitation Engineering
description: This subject equips civil engineering students with key environmental concepts and the impacts of engineering activities on the environment. It bridges academic knowledge with real-world challenges in planning and executing civil engineering projects, emphasising the interplay between engineering, the environment, and society. You'll develop awareness of environmental issues, understand the effects of construction on natural systems, and learn strategies to reduce air, water, soil, and noise pollution. The subject also covers water pollution control design. You'll gain knowledge and critical skills for wastewater treatment, environmental management, and resource protection, enhancing your ability to create economically viable and environmentally sustainable structures.

title: Environmental Engineering Principles and Practice Studio
description: This developing studio promotes a holistic approach to solving complex environmental challenges, with a strong emphasis on water quality and treatment. You will engage in multidisciplinary projects that integrate chemical, physical, and biological principles to analyse data and develop innovative design solutions. Through team-based, open-ended projects, you will explore the complexities of real-world engineering practice. Weekly studio workshops will support the development of both theoretical understanding and practical application. The focus on collaboration enhances your skills in design, teamwork, communication, and project management. By the end of the studio, you will be prepared to address environmental challenges with technical competence and professional responsibility.

title: Environmental Planning and Law
description: This subject introduces you to key concepts and principles of environmental law to protect human health, biodiversity, and the environment in the context of resource management and land use planning. You will explore the evolution of environmental legislation and regulations and their role in development planning and resource management, particularly in NSW. You will also gain an understanding of NSW planning legislation, the planning process, and land use constraints, enhancing your ability to navigate legal, social, and environmental challenges in engineering projects. The subject also aims to improve your communication skills in legal contexts and provide a conceptual and technical grasp of environmental planning and law. You'll engage with topics like biodiversity conservation and the operation of the Environment Protection Authority, major environmental acts, and court decisions on development applications and pollution control. Through tutorials and case studies, you will discuss contemporary environmental law cases, culminating in a discussion paper on an engineering-related environmental issue, preparing you to collaborate effectively with legal professionals.

title: Exchange Elective 1 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with the foundational knowledge and skills for a career in child and family health, emphasising evidence-based practice and health promotion. You'll learn to apply primary healthcare principles to support families effectively. Through online resources, interactive activities and case studies based on real-world examples, you'll develop critical thinking and problem-solving abilities. Reflective exercises will enhance your understanding and ability to articulate insights within this vital healthcare sector.

title: Exchange Elective 2 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with a comprehensive understanding of community health, emphasising the collective role in supporting families. You will learn to assess family dynamics, identify stressors during transitions, and apply a strengths-based approach to foster family and community well-being. You'll gain an increased appreciation of the significant role the family plays in relation to the mental and physical health and wellbeing of its members and to the health of the whole community. Through interactive resources, case studies and reflective activities, you'll enhance your critical thinking and develop practical skills for effective family engagement, preparing you to positively impact mental and physical health within communities.

title: Exchange Elective 3 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with vital skills to support families with infants up to two years old, focusing on normal development, attachment theory, and managing common infant behaviours. You'll learn to conduct thorough assessments and advise on feeding, nutrition, and sleep, enhancing your ability to bolster parental confidence and provide social support. Your learning involves active engagement with online resources, critical analysis through varied multimedia, and practical problem-solving activities. You'll also gain hands-on experience through a mandatory clinical program in an early childhood health setting, complemented by real-world case studies and immediate feedback, fostering reflective and informed practice.

title: Exchange Elective 4 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with vital skills for engaging with families and their preschool children, focusing on normal developmental variations and behavioural assessments for ages three to five. You'll learn to conduct comprehensive evaluations, offer guidance to parents, and foster social support networks.Learning is interactive, utilising online resources, case studies, and real-world examples to develop your understanding and critical thinking. You'll engage in problem-solving and reflective activities, receiving immediate feedback to refine your practice The subject requires the successful completion of a clinical experience program in an early childhood health facility.

title: Exchange Elective 5 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with an understanding of the unique health challenges facing women in Australia, highlighting how gender biases affect healthcare. You'll gain insights into the social, biomedical, and behavioural factors shaping women's health, applying theories from your health discipline. Learning is interactive, utilising online resources, multimedia, and real-world case studies to foster critical thinking. Activities include problem-solving tasks and reflective exercises, all designed to enhance your analytical skills with immediate feedback and expert guidance.

title: Exchange Elective 6 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with a comprehensive understanding of sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) in developing countries and crisis situations. You'll engage with historical and contemporary policy frameworks, develop knowledge about reproductive justice, and develop your analytical skills through a global SRHR perspective, enabling you to engage in critical dialogue and action. Learning is interactive, utilising online multimedia, real-world case studies and expert podcasts to deepen your understanding of SRHR challenges.

title: Exchange Elective 7 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with an understanding of how modern societal and environmental factors affect children's health and wellbeing. You'll explore the impact of contemporary life on various aspects of child development and learn to analyse health challenges faced by young people through different theoretical lenses. Your skills in critical thinking and understanding will be honed through interactive online resources, stimulating multimedia materials, and problem-solving tasks. Learning is reinforced with real-world case studies and immediate feedback, fostering reflective and analytical competencies in a guided, yet self-directed environment.

title: Exchange Elective 8 (Information Technology)
description: This subject equips you with a comprehensive understanding of reproductive health, vital for supporting individuals on their fertility journey. You'll gain insights into the anatomy, physiology, and hormonal mechanisms that inform fertility treatments, including assisted reproductive technology (ART). You'll also acquire the skills to educate and assist clients through fertility processes and collaborate effectively within a healthcare team. Learning involves tracing a typical fertility treatment trajectory, from initial consultation to potential outcomes, ensuring you can guide clients with empathy and expertise. Your skills in critical thinking and understanding will be honed through interactive online resources, stimulating multimedia materials, and problem-solving tasks. Learning is reinforced with real-world case studies and immediate feedback, fostering reflective and analytical competencies in a guided, yet self-directed environment.

title: Exchange Elective A
description: This subject is used for the purpose of enrolling students participating in the UTS Global Exchange Program. The program offers students the opportunity to complete one or two sessions of study with an international exchange partner institution and receive credit towards their course at UTS. Applicants must have their study at the partner institution approved by the faculty prior to enrolment in this subject.

description: This subject is used for the purpose of enrolling students participating in the UTS Global Exchange Program. The program offers students the opportunity to complete one or two sessions of study with an international exchange partner institution and receive credit towards their course at UTS. Applicants must have their study at the partner institution approved by the faculty prior to enrolment in this subject.

description: This subject is used for the purpose of enrolling students participating in the UTS Global Exchange Program. The program offers students the opportunity to complete one or two sessions of study with an international exchange partner institution and receive credit towards their course at UTS. Applicants must have their study at the partner institution approved by the faculty prior to enrolment in this subject.

title: Factory Modelling and Simulation
description: This subject delves into the simulation of factory and manufacturing processes, an essential aspect of advanced manufacturing. You'll learn to use state-of-the-art modelling techniques to predict and evaluate the performance of production facilities and equipment. Through hands-on demonstrations and industrial case studies, you will experience the complexities of creating simulations and gain the skills to implement them in various manufacturing contexts, preparing you to leverage digital technologies in the field.

title: Finance and IT Professionals
description: This subject will equip you with skills in financial management that are essential to any IT professional working in business today. Students gain knowledge of financial principles and an understanding of reporting requirements which are necessary for the evaluation and design of auditable financial systems. In addition, students develop key competencies in the financial aspects of IT management, outsourcing and project management including budgeting, statement analysis, feasibility and risk management.

title: Fluid Mechanics
description: This subject provides a comprehensive introduction to fluid behaviour under static and dynamic conditions, including the underlying principles and assumptions crucial for the design and optimisation of pipelines, water treatment plants, air conditioning systems, and aircraft. The subject also encourages you to explore fluid mechanics in the real-world applications, fostering interest for further specialised study or research. Key topics include fluid properties, statics, kinematics, conservation laws, differential flow analysis, dimensional analysis, pipe flow, flow measurements, and external flow.
