You will acquire problem-solving and critical thinking skills and hands-on skills in experimentation and data analysis acquired through workshops, tutorials and laboratory practices.

title: Foundations of Electrical and Electronic Technology
description: This subject delves into essential concepts and technologies in electrical and electronic engineering, covering the principles of engineering electromagnetics and their practical applications in various devices. From amplifiers and transformers to motors, antennas, and even wireless power transfer systems, you will explore how these technologies operate and interact. By mastering the design and analysis of low-frequency electromagnetic devices and high-frequency electronic components, you will be equipped to tackle challenges in power/energy systems, telecommunications, and electronics. Engaging laboratory sessions further reinforce your understanding through hands-on exercises in electrical safety, measurements, and design verification, preparing you with essential practical skills for real-world applications in the field.

title: Fundamentals of Automation and Robotics
description: In this subject you will develop a foundational understanding and skills in automation and robotics for industrial processes. This includes developing knowledge of automation principles, programmable logic controllers (PLCs), feedback control including proportional-integral-differential (PID), sequential control, robot kinematics and trajectory planning.

title: Fundamentals of Biomedical Engineering Studio A
description: This subject introduces you to biomedical engineering, focusing on medical device signal processing and the technology used in  molecular diagnostics for disease. You'll engage in studio-based learning,  tackling real-life medical challenges to improve patient health outcomes. The subject covers processing and modelling physiological signals for medical devices, and teaches the basic steps of genome sequencing  while giving insights the application of such biomedical areas. Furthermore, it will provide views on  career opportunities using the skills obtained in the studio.

title: Fundamentals of Biomedical Engineering Studio B
description: This studio-based subject immerses you in the applications of biomaterials in regenerative medicine, and nanobiotechnology in cancer diagnosis, focusing on 3D printing technique for biomedical implants, and nanotechnology for cancer cell imaging. You'll gain practical skills in 3D modelling, printing and testing bone implants, as well as in designing and constructing optical nanoprobes for cancer cells labelling with nanoparticles and biological molecules. Collaborative projects will guide you from concept to prototype, using SOLIDWORKS for design and 3D printing for realisation. Additionally, you'll learn techniques of cell culture, cell staining, nanoparticles modification, antibody conjugations for cancer cells labelling and imaging, culminating in a solid grasp of the modelling and manufacturing processes in biomedical engineering as well as design, modification and imaging in nanobiotechnology.

title: Fundamentals of C Programming
description: In this subject, you will focus on the C programming language and will learn how to collect, process, and store data. You will explore essential programming concepts like conditional statements, loops, functions, arrays, file handling, data structures, and managing memory with pointers. You will also learn how to compile C code, link files, and run your programs using the GNU toolchain. You will experience the full development cycle just like an embedded/low-level system programmer, from analysing complex problems to designing, coding, debugging, and testing your solutions in C. This hands-on approach ensures you gain practical skills and confidence in programming.

title: Fundamentals of Interaction Design
description: This subject develops your ability to design, evaluate, and implement interactive systems with a human-centered approach. You'll understand human-computer interaction (HCI) and interaction design principles, learning key concepts, tools, and techniques. You'll also consider how designers' metaphors for human activity affect system usability and how human-centered design and evaluation can enhance interactive systems.

title: Fundamentals Studio A
description: This studio, the first in the fundamentals stage for Data and Electronic Engineering majors, moves beyond traditional curricula to foster an environment where you can apply and expand your knowledge through practical experience. It's centred on product development, requiring collaborative work in the studio with peers, academics, and industry mentors. You'll undertake a mix of self-directed study and team-based project work, progressing through stages of assessment, design, and implementation, mirroring the classic engineering process. Guided by a learning contract set at the start, you'll focus on acquiring fundamental skills and knowledge to realise basic product functionality, with an emphasis on creativity, technical expertise, teamwork, communication, and project management. Utilise this opportunity to delve into new topics that complement your coursework and personal interests.

title: Fundamentals Studio B
description: In this second studio of the Data and Electronic Engineering fundamentals stage, you're not confined to a standard curriculum but given the freedom to apply and enhance your knowledge through doing. The studio is a dynamic workspace where you'll collaborate with peers, academics, and industry mentors on product-based projects, blending individual study with team effort. Through the engineering process—assess, design, implement—you learn to apply knowledge to practical achievements. A learning contract directs your individual tasks from the outset. Here, you'll build on fundamental knowledge and skills to create a functioning product, emphasising creativity, diverse methods, technical growth, teamwork, communication, and project management. This studio is your chance to broaden your understanding by integrating new, personally interesting topics with previous coursework.

title: Game Design Methodologies
description: This games subject trains you to be an engineer of entertainment, teaching you the essential theoretical concepts and practical methodologies for game design. You will learn to structure, document, target, and scope your game designs with further refinement through weekly iteration via playtest feedback. As part of a group, you will first learn to apply these creative theories and methods to develop a physical board game prototype before moving on to crafting a digital game using a popular game engine. While this subject is not focused on game development skills such as coding or art creation, you are encouraged to self-learn what's necessary to realise your group’s vision. Regular playtesting with peers will help refine your designs. By the subject's end, you'll have created both board and digital games, showcasing your interaction design expertise for future employment portfolios.  You will be better prepared for the iterative development cycle common in later game studio subjects and the wider game industry.

title: Game Design Studio 1
description: In this subject, you will learn the practical aspects of game design and development by creating games that meet client specifications. You'll explore game mechanics from indie and experimental games to inform your own creations, adopting a player-centric design philosophy with constant user testing. Collaborative teamwork mirrors industry practices, with you taking on specific roles and working independently yet guided, culminating in responsibility for delivering and presenting the final project.

title: Game Design Studio 2
description: This subject hones your practical skills in game design and development through multidisciplinary team collaboration, following Agile Project Management Principles. You will work closely with students from other Faculties, and you'll specialise in areas like 3D modeling, scripting, level design, or music composition, contributing to the creation of commercial-quality video games. Your team, which retains the intellectual property rights, is encouraged to market your game post-completion, aligning with the dynamic nature of the games industry and offering real-world application potential.

title: Geotechnical Engineering
description:
This subject enhances your technical competence in analysing soil masses and structures interacting with soil, such as footings, piles, retaining walls, and slopes. You will learn to understand soil failure, select appropriate analysis methods, recognise limitations, validate solutions, and contribute to design teams. The subject encourages engagement with literature and application of advanced analysis methods, alongside fieldwork for subsurface investigations.

Key topics include geotechnical design principles, site investigation techniques, shallow and deep foundation design, earth pressure theories, retaining structure analysis, slope stability assessment, and soil improvement strategies. You'll gain the skills to critically evaluate geotechnical problems, apply engineering judgment, and understand the role of codes in design.

title: Google Industry Studio
description: This studio subject concentrates on practical application development with GCP, designed to immerse students in a Google sub-major into a dynamic, practice-based learning setting. You'll develop professional competence through reflective design practice, teamwork, mentoring, and deep learning techniques.

title: Heat and Mass Transfer
description: This foundational subject delves into the fundamentals of heat and mass transfer, teaching you to develop transport models from first principles. You will study how temperature and concentration gradients form within and across boundary layers. The subject applies the principles of heat and mass transfer to various contexts, including multi-stage processes and natural and forced convection, as well as phase transitions. By the end, you'll be adept at solving heat and mass transfer system problems and recommending solutions relevant to the chemical process industries.

title: Honours Project
description: In this advanced stage of your honours programme, you'll complete a research project, building on prior work and guided by an academic supervisor. You'll develop and showcase your ability to conduct independent research, solve complex problems, and present your findings with scholarly rigour. Your learning will be self-directed, culminating in a project that either delivers a system, creative work or contributes to academic research, reflecting the depth of knowledge and skills acquired throughout your studies. Progress will be monitored through regular discussions with your supervisor, ensuring you meet the high expectations and timelines necessary for graduation readiness

title: Human-centred Design Methods
description: This subject focuses on making people the core of the interaction design process through human-centred design methods, with particular attention to interviewing and probes. Interviewing gathers direct information and adapts flexibly across the design process, while probes, using tailored props, require more setup but can inspire creative insights. You'll learn both methods, applying them step-by-step to real participants, guided by a brief and with readings and examples to tailor your approach. You must recruit at least three strangers (people you do not know) for interviews and one for the probe study.

title: Human-machine Interfaces and Perception
description: In this subject you will learn about the multidisciplinary field of robotics and automation engineering in both theory and practice at an intermediate level. As an outcome of this subject, you will have developed an understanding of topics of sensing and machine perception algorithms and human-machine interfaces.

title: Hydraulics and Hydrology
description: This subject provides you with a foundation in predicting water quantity (hydrology) and its movement (hydraulics), equipping you with the scientific principles and practical skills to tackle integrated hydraulic and hydrologic issues. Building on fluid mechanics knowledge, the subject introduces hydrology and essential design skills in water engineering. You'll explore core concepts relevant to open channel hydraulics, surface water hydrology, and design flood estimation, enabling you to apply these methods to a variety of water-related problems.

title: Image Processing and Pattern Recognition
description: This subject provides an understanding of image processing and pattern recognition principles, enabling the development of software for automatic image and video analysis. You'll gain skills akin to professional engineers in this field and apply them to real-world problems, like video surveillance detection and automated medical diagnosis, in a team-based project. The aim is to equip you with the ability to scope, solve, test, and communicate solutions effectively.

title: Industrial Engineering
description: This subject addresses the imperative for operational excellence in dynamic organisational environments, grounding you in Industrial Engineering principles that tackle the challenges of planning and optimising production systems. Lean Management, a pivotal approach for enhancing productivity and reducing waste, is central to this subject and extends its relevance beyond manufacturing. You will acquire the methods and tools necessary to structure and standardise workflows, devise assembly concepts, manage material supply, and conduct feasibility studies, all with the goal of creating efficient and productive work systems.

title: Industrial IoT Studio
description: This studio introduces the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT), preparing you for careers in digitally-transformed industries, particularly manufacturing. You'll develop skills to support the shift to connected factories by tackling a specific industry-focussed design problem. The subject covers IIoT technologies and applications, software (like IoT middleware, dashboards, and databases), and hardware (sensors and actuators). You'll gain practical experience in designing and implementing IIoT systems using industry-standard equipment, positioning you at the forefront of this technological evolution.

title: Industrial Robotics
description: This introductory subject on industrial robotics arms you with an understanding of robot manipulator representation, kinematics, and control. You'll explore the diverse tasks that robots can undertake and, in teams, construct a simulated industrial robot, developing both the model and the necessary control and planning software. Safety is a core component, with a focus on integrating safe design and operating procedures to mitigate risks. Additionally, the subject prompts critical thinking on the ethical implications of the growing presence of robots in industry and daily life, including the socioeconomic impacts on the human workforce.

title: Industry Experience 1 (BIT)
description: During your work placement, you'll engage with both academic and industry mentors through regular meetings, prepare  a learning contract to address a pertinent problem or opportunity at work. You'll present your progress on-site, with academic and industry mentors in attendance. Your learning, aimed at developing a portfolio of skills and achievements, occurs on the job, under the mentorship of industry and academic professionals. Together, you'll select specific SFIA skills to develop to proficiency level 3 (apply) through your placement activities. These individualised learning contracts guide your activities and, upon completion of your placement, serve as the basis for assessing your skills proficiency.

title: Industry Experience 2 (BIT)
description: While on work placement, you'll select professional skills to enhance to SFIA level 4 (enable), using workplace projects as a practical learning environment. Your application of these skills will deepen your understanding and contribute to a portfolio showcasing your expertise. With the support of industry and academic mentors, you'll identify skills to develop through your placement activities. Tailored learning contracts will steer your learning, and at the placement's end, these contracts will assess your proficiency level.

title: Information Security and Management
description: This subject focuses on training you in IT security policy development and human security management while addressing critical legal and ethical considerations. You will lay the groundwork for applying cyber safety and security measures at a corporate level. By conducting security assessments within business constraints, you will learn to employ professional methodologies effectively. The subject also covers the systematic evaluation of business and security operations, equipping you with skills in contingency planning, risk assessment, risk management, and compliance across diverse business environments. You'll be prepared to develop comprehensive security policies and manage human factors in cybersecurity, ensuring robust protection and ethical governance within organisations.

title: Information System Development Methodologies
description: This subject arms you with the techniques to navigate the complexities of information system design and development, acknowledging there's no one-size-fits-all solution. You'll learn to assess various methodologies, pinpointing their strengths and weaknesses, a critical skill for effective software project management.

title: Information Systems Capstone
description: This subject equips you with Information Systems (IS) skills tailored to your career ambitions, blending self-study with project work. You'll hone critical IS competencies and apply them in practice, supported by mentors. You will work with mentors and facilitators throughout the session, and the individual tasks to be completed will be guided by a learning contract established at the beginning of the studio.

title: Innovations for Global Relationship Management
description: This subject explores the evolving role of the Australian computing industry, emphasising its shift towards leveraging computers for relationship maintenance, knowledge management, and innovation to gain competitive advantage. You'll examine the industry's global context, the value of IT in business, and the implications of e-commerce, customer relationship management, user modelling, outsourcing, offshoring, and legal issues in the digital economy. The subject also addresses organising business information, focusing on informal flows within organisations, and examines various work relationships, team formation, and management processes. Practical skills include using portals and other tools for customer loyalty and outsourcing collaborations.

title: Integrated Electronic Systems Design
description: This subject provides an introduction to the fundamentals of electronics engineering and the electronics industry through practical lab and project work. You will learn the principles of basic analogue circuits, including signal processing and acquisition. The projects, both individual and team-based, involve constructing circuits based on the knowledge gained in class. You will also become proficient in using circuit simulation and layout software such as Advanced Design System (ADS), and MATLAB for circuit modelling and analysis.

title: Integrated Product Development for Industry 4.0
description: Product development creates a new technical product/system to fulfil specific needs and requirements. The resulting product design directly affects the entire product life cycle, such as manufacturing, maintenance and recycling. Thus, product development cannot happen in isolation but has to be part of an integrated product life cycle spanning approach. In this respect, Advanced Manufacturing creates new challenges but also offers new opportunities for such an integrated approach. You will learn to apply an integrated product development methodology, which will enable you to systematically develop new technical products. A key focus is on identifying relevant socio-technical needs and requirements across the entire product life cycle. You will develop a product to deepen your learning experience.

title: Intelligent Control Studio
description: This studio subject focuses on aspects of advanced control engineering design for multivariable systems. This subject will provide you a rich and attractive practice-based learning environment to gain advanced control engineering skills, essential for managing complex, multivariable systems such as power grids and aircraft. You will become proficiency in sophisticated control techniques beyond classical methods, enhancing your ability to design and implement systems that handle nonlinear dynamics. Learning is hands-on, blending theory with practice as you progress from concept to product realisation. Through reflective design, teamwork, and deep learning, you will prepare for senior roles, mastering design, simulation, and practical validation of advanced control systems.

title: Interaction Design Studio
description: In this capstone project, you will integrate your accumulated knowledge and skills by planning, developing, and producing an interactive product within a collaborative team environment. You're encouraged to critically innovate and experiment, addressing specific needs and contributing originality to the interaction design field. Additionally, the subject offers a platform to consider the future evolution of your product and career opportunities in the industry.

title: Interactive 3D Animation
description:
This subject delves into 3D animation for interactive applications like games or short animated productions, covering the entire production pipeline from storyboarding to animation, camera positioning, interactive control, code integration, lighting, advanced real-time rendering, and VFX.
You will actively engage in pre-production planning, practical realisation, and post-production with a game engine and a project-based approach emphasising learning by doing. This hands-on experience equips you with the skills to manage, enhance, and integrate animated components into games or to execute a complete animation project.

title: Interactive Media
description: This subject introduces you to the fundamentals of interactive media, preparing you to design and develop systems that integrate digital audio, images, animation, and video for immersive user experiences. You will gain proficiency in creative coding tools and techniques, applying them to create compelling content for various domains such as gaming, arts, and data visualisation. The emphasis is on practical application, ensuring that you can craft interactive media that captivate users in real-world scenarios.

title: Internet of Things
description: This subject introduces essential components of contemporary Internet of Things (IoT) system, including sensing/actuating techniques, IoT Communiations, IoT networks and intelligent IoT signal and data processing. You will learn the fundamentals of these aspects, with popular and futuristic techniques. You'll also learn how IoT integrates sensor networks, telemetry, data processing, and AI to inform business applications, with use cases ranging from environmental monitoring to robotic control. Through hands-on exercises and tasks in labs, you will implement many small yet interesting IoT projects, gaining practical insights into IoT working principles. A range of assessments are available for examining your learning performance, including quizzes, labs, projects, and exams.

title: Internet Science
description: This subject takes you to the forefront of networking, emphasising Internet measurement and research literature. Rather than studying networking concepts in isolation, you'll gain knowledge and skills by engaging with current research, aiming to understand, reproduce, and even expand upon existing studies. You'll work closely with research papers and real Internet data sets, following a master-apprentice approach in interactive tutorials and labs, where mathematical theory meets practical skills. Assessments include reports, an oral exam, lab write-ups with code, and online quizzes. The subject demands proficiency in Matlab for data analysis and Unix CLI tools. Prior experience with Matlab or strong programming skills are essential. You'll explore the data-driven domain of Internet measurement, a precursor to 'Big Data' and a key component of the evolving field of 'Data Science' focused on the Internet.

title: Internetworking Project
description: This subject will consolidate your understanding of internetworking-related theoretical knowledge and its application to practical projects. Enhancing your teamwork skills, you'll work collaboratively through project specification, design, and implementation.

title: Interrogating Technology: Sustainability, Environment and Social Change
description: This subject equips you with the skills to examine the relationship between engineering and society through philosophical, sociological, and political lenses. You'll be introduced to theoretical frameworks and research tools to investigate stakeholder perspectives on complex issues and their influence on policy. Through case studies of new technologies and engineering projects, you'll apply this learning directly to your engineering context, gaining a deeper understanding of the multifaceted interactions at play.

title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
description: This subject enhances your grasp of Artificial Intelligence (AI), covering learning, natural language processing, computer vision, search, knowledge representation, and reasoning. With lectures and practical labs focused on specific AI techniques, you'll learn to select appropriate models and algorithms for tasks and apply AI methods in simple applications. You will be assessed by a knowledge test, a set of mini-AI application examples and a group project addressing a real-world problem using AI technique, reflecting your ability for exemplifying AI applications and designing AI solutions in practical scenarios.

title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Biomedical engineering merges engineering principles with medical sciences to improve healthcare, covering diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation. It involves a spectrum of technologies, from pacemakers to cutting-edge developments like stem cell engineering and 3D organ printing. In this subject you will explore key areas such as tissue engineering, imaging, and nanotechnology, equipping you with the knowledge to innovate solutions for medical challenges through lectures, labs, and collaborative projects.

title: Introduction to Chemical Process Engineering
description: This subject equips you with the theory and practice of chemical process engineering, focusing on the industrial-scale transformation of raw materials into valuable products. You'll explore foundational theoretical concepts including mass and energy balances, thermodynamics, and transport phenomena including hands on practical lab classes. The subject also covers industrial unit operations like mass, and heat transfer, as well as chemical polymer reaction, hydrogen energy and chemical pollutant. Additionally, you'll delve into process design, control, chemical risk assessment, and plant operation, preparing you for the practical challenges of the field.

title: Introduction to Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: This subject imparts a foundational understanding of Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE), crucial for creating and maintaining infrastructure in both urban and rural areas. You'll develop core skills in design, solution presentation, report writing, and technical drawing, contextualised through diverse civil infrastructure projects. These projects will also require you to consider social, economic, and environmental factors. The subject lays the groundwork for advanced education in design, construction, operation, and maintenance of civil infrastructure and fosters the individual and collaborative skills needed for CEE project analysis and execution.

title: Introduction to Computer Game Development
description: This subject introduces you to game development using a commercial-grade game engine, focusing on building a strong foundation in generalisable virtual interaction simulation theory and intermediate programming problem solving skills in the Unity Game Engine. You'll become familiar with industry terminology, engine interface tools, vector and matrix maths for object transformation, and programming involving the engine API. You will be assessed on your practical skills development through weekly lab content to ensure consistent skill development over the session. You will create a classic video game over the semester, beginning with the asset creation and import into the engine, and then programming the game logic akin to the original game experience. You will also craft a level with a unique twist to allow for you to develop your creative problem-solving skills, a crucial skill for any aspiring game developer. The skills developed in this subject will prepare you to contribute effectively to group projects in future game-related subjects and subject outcomes can be utilised in an employment portfolio.

title: Introduction to Data Analytics
description: This subject covers the fundamentals of data analytics, blending art and science to transform large, complex datasets into actionable insights. You will learn data preprocessing, exploration, visualization, and predictive modeling using various data analytics techniques. By connecting cutting-edge research with practical applications, this subject prepares you to undertake data mining projects, collaborate with analytics professionals, and effectively communicate your findings.

title: Introduction to Data Engineering
description: This subject lays the groundwork for understanding data engineering and its role in today's data-driven world. You'll actively engage in designing data collection experiments, processing and analysing data, and visualising it effectively for informed decision-making. You'll gather your own datasets or work with existing datasets for class activities and a culminating project. Proficiency in MATLAB, essential for modelling and analysis, is a key outcome. The subject is a core component for Data Science Engineering majors but is also open to students from other disciplines seeking to enhance their data engineering skills.

title: Introduction to Electrical and Electronic Engineering
description: This subject introduces you to engineering, emphasising problem identification, solution proposal, and implementation. It acknowledges the contextual nature of engineering, its real-world impact, and its reliance on scientific principles. Electrical and electronic engineering, which underpins our modern world, is a key focus. Central to the subject is a real-world problem and its electronic solution, serving as a basis for exploring both technical and non-technical aspects of engineering. You'll learn fundamental electrical concepts such as voltage, current, resistance, and power, alongside basic circuit analysis for DC and AC circuits, and the roles of capacitors and inductors. Practical skills are prioritised, with labs dedicated to circuit construction, testing, and troubleshooting, and using instruments like multimeters and oscilloscopes.

title: Introduction to Engineering Projects
description:
This core subject exposes you to new ways of working, ideas regarding the scope of what engineering actually is, considerations regarding engineering in the Australian context, as well as the broad impacts engineering decisions have on people, community and the environment. Through authentic engineering experiences you will build your professional skills and knowledge, providing a solid foundation for your continuous professional development journey as a future engineer.

The subject is centred around completing the Engineers Without Borders Challenge for which you will work in a team to develop engineering solutions to local real-world challenges on behalf of a partner Australian Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Community Organisation. You will form a team with peers and working together in and outside class you will research and refine the problem and design considerations, ideate and prototype potential solutions that will work in the community context, and ultimately propose a fully developed design idea that would benefit the partner community. In completing the challenge you will develop your professional interdisciplinary skills such as research skills, learn and apply the engineering design process, develop an understanding of and consider socio-technical issues, build your professional communications skills in engineering contexts, and learn to lead and participate in team processes.

title: Introduction to Information Systems
description: This subject examines the integration and application of IT technology within society, business, government, and community systems, highlighting trends like increased mobility, complexity, globalisation, and networking in a data-centric world. It explores how IT technology enhances service delivery and competitiveness in a global, networked economy. You'll learn the role of information systems in business management and network formation, using real-world case studies to grasp how IS contributes to competitive advantage. The subject covers IS development, implementation, and maintenance, while also fostering team collaboration and relationship skills. Ethical, privacy, and security considerations are also addressed. You'll apply theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios, innovate, and cultivate teamwork skills.

title: Introduction to Innovation
description: This subject equips you with an understanding of innovation, commercialisation, technology life cycles, and change in engineering and technology. It prepares you for the commercial world by developing your understanding of different roles within an enterprise through a business planning framework. Covering strategy, marketing, operations, personnel, and finance, it offers a practical orientation with contemporary case studies to illustrate concept application. As you approach the end of your undergraduate studies, this knowledge will enable you to communicate effectively with various organisational functions.

title: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering
description: This subject introduces you to the fundamentals of engineering visualisation and design, from sketching and drawing to computer-aided design and solid modelling. You will learn to represent components graphically through sketching and computer methods, employing standard techniques like orthogonal projection. The subject also covers basic engineering mechanics, enabling you to analyse simple machines and structures, and introduces engineering management tools, which you will apply in the design and hands-on construction of a mechanical prototype.

title: Introduction to Mechatronics Engineering
description: This subject equips you with the foundational knowledge and skills to design mechatronic systems, offering an early introduction to electronic components and coding within a mechanical engineering context. You'll engage in a studio-like project that encourages creative and critical thinking, setting the stage for the studio approach you'll encounter more frequently in advanced studies. This practical foundation is directly relevant to both your academic journey and future work experiences.

title: Introduction to Software Development
description: This subject introduces the fundamentals of modern software development. You will learn agile and non-agile software development principles, methods, tools, and techniques, and explore current trends and challenges in software development. You will also learn how to design, develop, and evaluate software that implements commercially realistic but manageably small requirements. Teaching is delivered through pre-recorded lectures and hands-on workshops. In your weekly workshops and assessment tasks, you will be given assignments to modify or extend existing software features or functions and, at times, to create new ones. You will be encouraged to practice peer learning and collaboration, but ultimately, you must complete your tasks independently. By successfully completing this subject, you will experience, understand the importance of, and be able to apply sound professional practices in software development.

title: Introductory Digital Systems
description: This subject equips you with a solid understanding of digital systems and programmable electronic circuits and their applications in engineering. You'll master the hardware architecture of small computer systems and learn to write basic assembly code. Key topics include digital combinational and sequential circuits, state diagrams, microcontroller architecture, machine-level software integration, low-level programming, interrupts, I/O, and hardware interfacing design techniques.

title: Introductory Embedded Systems
description: This subject covers the essentials of embedded systems, including microcontroller architectures, fundamental microcontroller components, such as IO, timer, serial communications, embedded system design and analysis techniques, and embedded programming. You will learn fundamental knowledge and first principles, allowing you to go much further beyond the introductory level. You'll also gain practical skills through extensive hands-on lab exercises and tasks, as well as group projects, where you learn and experience designing, programming, debugging, testing and pitching your embedded systems. A range of assessments are available for examining your learning performance, including quizzes, labs, projects, and exams.

title: iOS industry Studio
description: This studio is designed to enhance your practical iOS application development skills to become professionally competent. You will participate in reflective design practices, collaborate in teams, receive mentorship and learn advanced techniques. This hands-on learning experience will provide you with a comprehensive understanding of the iOS development environment and its frameworks to deliver real-world applications.

title: IS Data Visualisation Studio
description:
Taking the Information Systems (IS) perspective, rather than the more common Data Science or IT perspectives, this subject focuses on the latest developments and professional practices in data visualisation and visual analytics for non-technical decision-makers. Recognising the importance of data visualisation literacy in various disciplines, including IS, this subject stands out by emphasising (i) understanding the reasons behind using data visualisation in addition to learning how to create them, (ii) identifying business and organisational cases along with their requirements, stakeholders, and problem space, (iii) visual ethics and the responsible use of visual data, and (iv) utilising commercial data visualisation software instead of elaborate coding.
In short, the subject aims for visual problem exploration “through data” rather than the creation of static visual outputs. To achieve this, you will be taught through a combination of lectures and studios with a focus on design thinking exercises and ethical visual analytics. You will develop the necessary skills and mindset for problem finding and solving through visual data exploration that goes beyond creating static visual outputs. These skills include identifying different stakeholders and analysing their decision-making needs and environments, problem formulation, finding and ethically harvesting relevant data, ensuring data quality, data integration, multidimensional modelling, and developing a data exploration prototype using commercial data visualisation software.
Focusing on value creation and the decision-making needs of different stakeholders, you will also learn how to use data-driven visual storytelling and other contemporary techniques to explore the problem space, inform, influence, and inspire various types of stakeholders, including those in business and IT.

title: IT Experience Review
description: This subject enhances your readiness for the IT industry by refining your professional skills and leveraging insights from work-integrated learning experiences. You'll develop key professional artefacts, including a portfolio, CV, and self-presentation techniques, to strengthen your job applications. The subject includes four interactive 2-hour workshops and culminates in a Professional Practice & Leadership Forum, where you'll present your work to industry professionals. You'll also form a Peer Review Group (PRG) for collaborative learning during and outside lectures. Participation in the Forum is mandatory, with Special Consideration available under specific circumstances.

title: IT Operations Management
description: In this subject, you will develop the skills necessary for managing resources in an information systems organisation, including hardware, software, and personnel. You will learn about resource acquisition, software development, workplace management, recruitment, training, security practices, operations management, and service level agreements. The subject also covers industry frameworks and standards such as ITIL, alongside contemporary topics like cloud computing, equipping you with a comprehensive skill set for effective IT resource management.

title: Machine Learning
description: This subject equips you with the skills to apply machine learning, a key driver of innovation across various industries, by teaching you to program and analyse intelligent systems that learn from data. You will develop a clear understanding of both foundational and advanced algorithms through practical exercises and theoretical study. Your learning experience will blend active engagement with real-world applications, particularly in artificial intelligence, preparing you for immediate professional application and further exploration in the field.

title: Machines and Mechanisms A
description: The subject provides insights into the behaviour of solid bodies in motion, making it essential for fields including mechanical engineering, manufacturing engineering, aerospace engineering, biomedical engineering, etc. It equips you with the ability to solve the movement of interconnected bodies under the influence of external forces. You'll delve into the kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in planar motion, including displacements, velocities, accelerations, forces, energy, impulse and momentum, and learn the energy method, in contrast to direct applications of Newton's second law of motion. By studying the dynamics of real mechanical systems, you will appreciate the relevance of dynamics in engineering machines and structures.

title: Manual Methods for Reverse Engineering
description: This micro-credential provides an introduction to the principles and practices of manual reverse engineering. The subject is structured to equip learners with the necessary skills and knowledge for accurately measuring physical objects using advanced tools such as computer metrology, vernier calipers, and micrometers. Students engage in detailed analysis and interpretation of measurement data, a critical step in constructing precise digital representations of physical entities. The subject also encompasses the application of manual reverse engineering techniques, essential for the reproduction of components in fields like manufacturing and quality assurance. This subject is designed to foster a thorough understanding of these processes, preparing students for professional applications in various technical domains.

title: Materials and Manufacturing Engineering A
description: This subject introduces you to engineering materials, their physical properties, and their integration into the design process. You will learn the principles of various manufacturing processes, i.e. casting, forming, machining, joining, powder metallurgy, heat treatment, surface treatment, and their influence on design. You will also learn the concept of additive manufacturing. By the end, you will possess fundamental knowledge for selecting suitable materials and manufacturing processes for specific components and applications.

title: Mechanical Design Fundamentals Studio 1
description: This first studio subject for Mechanical and Mechatronics Engineering students focuses on applying theoretical knowledge to a practical engineering challenge. You will engage in a design-and-build project, honing fundamental design skills by addressing a defined problem. The project involves going through the engineering design process to design and build a system for the Warman Design and Build Challenge. Success relies on effective teamwork, clear communication, and thorough documentation of the design process, including ideas, decisions, and justifications. Through the subject, you will enhance project management abilities, engineering documentation skills, and technical proficiency,  while showcasing creativity and collaboration.

title: Mechanical Design Fundamentals Studio 2
description: This studio subject expands on design methods from previous studies, introducing a systems thinking approach to complex thermo-fluidic system design, integrating both fluid and mechanical elements. You'll tackle a technical problem, applying systems thinking to devise a unique solution mindful of environmental and socio-economic impacts. This experience will enhance your ability to manage and innovate within the realm of heat and power transfer applications in engineering.

title: Mechanical Systems Design Studio 1
description: This studio subject enhances your ability to critically interpret engineering designs and make informed decisions. You'll dissect the fit, form, and function of designs, applying reverse engineering to deconstruct and understand underlying concepts. Your analysis will critique the design's suitability, leading to the creation of an improved second-generation design, backed by sound reasoning and thorough justification. This process will sharpen your evaluative skills and decision-making in modern engineering design.

title: Mechanical Systems Design Studio 2
description: This studio consolidates earlier concepts from foundational subjects and technical knowledge. You will learn and apply an established engineering systems design process that enables you to develop and design technical systems in a flexible yet systematic manner. Based on this, you'll tackle a broadly defined engineering problem, working in industry-style teams to deliver unique solutions. The project will expose you to key needs, requirements, and challenges of an industry-like project. The subject bridges engineering science and practice, concentrating on the methodical facets of engineering design, such as conducting relevant analyses and making informed technical decisions and recommendations.

title: Mechanics of Solids
description: This foundational subject aims to deepen your understanding of the behaviour of structural components in engineered structures and machines. You'll develop the ability to analyse these components under various loads and supports using equilibrium principles and material constitutional relationships. The subject covers a range of topics including beam pure bending, shear stresses, composite beams, beam deflection, column buckling, torsion in shafts and sections, stress transformation, inelastic bending, and combined stresses. You'll also learn about the product of inertia, principal axes and principal moments of inertia, unsymmetric bending, and the concept of the shear centre. This knowledge is essential for designing and analysing structural and machine components effectively.

title: Methods in Quantum Computing
description: This subject offers a structured introduction to quantum computing, a revolutionary technology poised to surpass traditional computing capabilities. You'll learn the fundamental principles, discover quantum algorithms, and acquire programming skills to develop software that leverages the extraordinary potential of quantum computers, preparing you for advancements expected in the near future.

title: Microelectronics
description: This subject will equip you to analyse and design microelectronic circuits and appreciate their application in communication systems and consumer electronics. You will learn about semiconductor physics, device characteristics of transistor and diodes, and apply this knowledge to circuit design. Through labs and projects, this subject will prepare you for advanced study or a career in the field of microelectronics.

title: Mobile Networking
description: Wireless networks, including cellular, WiFi, Bluetooth, satellite, and near-field communication networks, establish pervasive connections to devices and end-users, serving as foundational technologies across virtually all industries today. This subject explores the principles and applications of wireless telecommunications and their integration with the internet. It emphasizes key concepts, infrastructure, and protocols critical to these networks, particularly their ability to support a diverse array of devices and mobility needs. The subject includes guest lectures from leading Australian telecommunications companies, offering firsthand insights into the latest cellular technologies. You will gain extensive hands-on experience by addressing real-world industry challenges and developing either emulated sensing/communication systems or working prototypes in group projects. This approach not only imparts fundamental knowledge but also equips you with practical skills applicable across numerous engineering fields. By the end of this subject, you'll have a comprehensive understanding of wireless networks, equipped to engage with advanced technologies and innovations.

title: Natural Language Processing
description: This subject introduces you to Natural Language Processing (NLP), the field that processes and understands human languages. You'll explore core NLP technologies, such as text understanding, machine translation, and sentiment analysis, and apply them to practical problems. The subject offers cutting-edge theories and hands-on techniques, equipping you with the knowledge to embark on NLP research and develop real-world NLP applications.

title: Network Fundamentals
description: This subject offers a contemporary overview of computer networking, focusing on layered network architecture and the TCP/IP protocol suite, essential for data engineers to understand data transfer across the internet. You'll engage in practical exercises, such as monitoring live network traffic and creating network applications via socket programming. Additionally, you'll gain hands-on experience with Cisco network equipment to construct networks. The subject hones your problem-solving and design skills, enabling you to choose optimal network services and craft applications like web servers and clients for peak data performance.

title: Network Servers
description: This subject equips you with design principles and practical skills for deploying network servers using Windows and Linux operating systems. Your system administration techniques and skills will be developed through a well-designed combination of comprehensive laboratory exercises, focused mini-lectures, and design tasks.

title: Networked Enterprise Architecture
description: This subject explores how information systems support business networking and the sharing of information with partners to maintain a competitive edge. You'll learn enterprise architecture methodologies and design tools, enhancing problem-solving, critical thinking, and organisational skills through case studies. The subject emphasises the practical application of these skills in teamwork settings, preparing you to manage information effectively within an organisation.

title: Pollution Control and Waste Management
description: This subject provides an understanding of pollution control, waste management and practices. It addresses solid and hazardous waste issues, focusing on minimisation, treatment, and disposal. You'll explore solid waste generation, characterisation, composition analysis, collection optimisation, sanitary landfill design and management, and the social and environmental impacts. The subject also covers hazardous waste regulations, treatment design, disposal, and community engagement. Additionally, you'll study soil contamination and remediation techniques, including site assessment and case studies. The subject further delves into emerging pollution control technologies and process design improvements for reducing pollution in communities and industries. You'll also examine the control of specific pollutants from infrastructure such as wastewater treatment plants and waste disposal sites.

title: Power Electronics
description: This subject offers a comprehensive foundation in power electronics, which is a key technology driving the latest advancement in electrical engineering. The curriculum covers a range of important topics, including the study of semiconductor devices, passive components, converter topologies, and power conversion methods. By enrolling in this subject, you will develop a solid understanding of the principles and control strategies that govern the operation of power electronic converters. These converters play a crucial role in facilitating voltage, current, and frequency conversions that are essential for modern electrical systems. Through a combination of theory, laboratory work, and projects, you will acquire the skills necessary for analysing, designing, and implementing power electronic converters. Furthermore, you will gain essential knowledge in advanced topics such as thermal management, soft-switching techniques, and electromagnetic interference. With this knowledge, you will be well-prepared to design efficient power electronic systems and apply your expertise in practical, real-world scenarios. This includes electric power systems, renewable energy generation and storage, the Internet of Energy, and the electrification of transportation.

title: Power Systems Studio A
description: This studio equips you with practical skills in power systems modelling, analysis and design, essential for careers in electrical engineering. You'll learn to analyse synchronous machines, manage system stability, and control power flow, alongside understanding transmission line performance. Your learning combines self-study with collaborative projects, where you'll apply theory to a design product, guided by academic and industry experts. This blend of individual and teamwork ensures a comprehensive grasp of the subject matter.

title: Power Systems Studio B
description: This studio equips you with essential skills in power systems operation and protection, enhancing your understanding of power system faults and protection mechanisms. You'll learn to apply protection schemes such as overcurrent, differential, and distance protection in power networks, grasp the fundamentals of instrument transformers, and explore power economic dispatch. Additionally, you'll gain practical knowledge of demand side management, including smart metering and load forecasting, SCADA systems, and the electricity market. Your learning experience combines self-study with collaborative design projects, mentored by industry professionals, fostering both individual and team-based problem-solving skills.

title: Privacy Preserving
description: In this subject you'll master techniques for safeguarding data privacy, enabling organisations to handle personal or confidential data responsibly. The subject explores privacy models to build defenses against privacy breaches, delving into data anonymisation, statistical privacy approaches, and differential privacy, ensuring you can protect and manage sensitive information effectively.

title: Process Design and Safety Studio
description: This studio subject will develop your skills to design and manage complex engineering systems. You will work collaboratively on an authentic design project and produce design documentation. You will also explore the application of data analytics and data visualisation for the whole system performance monitoring and optimisation. You will undertake a Hazard and Operability analysis; conduct a social, economic, and environmental sustainability evaluation; and present your design to  stakeholders. Upon the completion of this subject, you will be ready to work in a chemical plant environment adhering to the safety requirements in designing and operating complex engineering systems.

title: Process Dynamics and Control
description: In this Pre-Professional subject, you will be introduced to mathematical tools for analysing the transient behaviour of open and closed-loop process systems. You will learn to apply methods to design and implement an automated process such as feedback control, feedforward control, cascade control, multi-loop control and model-based control. Instrumentation and control devices for automatic control and applications of emerging digital tools such as telemetry, virtual reality, and digital twins will also be covered. Upon the completion of this subject, you will have experience analysing the operation of modern process plants.

title: Process Simulation
description: In this Developing subject you will further your understanding of process modelling concepts covered in previous subjects such as Introduction to Chemical Process Engineering. This subject enables you to visualise how the equipment operates in terms of mass and energy balances and will cover topics such as familiarisation with simulation tools and building a unit operations process flow diagram. You will learn how to apply the principles of process simulation tool to model and analyse various industrial operation units, including pumps, distillation columns, mixers/splitters, heat exchangers, reactors, and separators. Additionally, you will set up and solve material and energy balances using simulation tools to develop a simple process model and run an analysis of basic process data. By the end of the semester, you will have a thorough understanding of chemical process simulation, including the application of process simulation tool to model and analyse complete industrial operation units. You will engage in peer learning and work on a group project based around a real-world problem which will build your collaboration skills and enhance your engagement and understanding of the practical applications of process simulation.

title: Production System Design
description: In this subject, you'll learn to analyse, design, and improve the configuration of production systems to meet the demands for variety and flexibility in manufacturing. You'll gain insights into classifying production systems, assessing performance, and understanding quality indicators. The subject also covers methods for configuring and sizing production systems, including buffering for production flows. Real-world case studies underscore the intricacies of system design, enhancing your practical understanding.

title: Professional Engineering Communication
description:
This subject is focused on developing your professional communication and critical thinking skills, deepening your understanding of the professional responsibilities of engineers (for example risk in projects) and how these apply to planning and managing engineering projects. I You'll engage with diverse communication mediums and documents essential for negotiating project facets with various audiences and stakeholders, focusing on the tendering process. You'll interpret, analyse, and present information to different audiences, enhancing your ability to evaluate engineering proposals through business, ethical, and project management lenses.
You will build on your experiences of engineering projects in Introduction to Engineering Projects and Designing Sustainable Engineering Projects, and expand on this to better understand the complexities of contemporary engineering practice. You will expands the scope of project evaluation introduced in Engineering Project Appraisal by highlighting the importance of communication with real people and their different interests, motivations, assumptions, and values in a business context. This also foreshadows the broader cross-cultural complexity which are explored further in Collaboration in Complex Projects with its Indigenous engineering theme.

title: Professional Experience 1
description: This subject serves as a practical foundation during your first engineering internship, This subject is complemented by the support activities in 41037 Work Integrated Learning 1. You'll develop real-world skills and apply classroom learning in a professional setting, enhancing your employability. The learning experience is hands-on, with direct industry or community engagement, fostering a deeper understanding of engineering practices.

title: Professional Experience 2
description: This subject is essentially a 'placeholder' for while you are working in industry or the community for the purpose of the second of your two engineering internships.

title: Professional Practice (BE)
description: This subject helps you articulate your professional engineering identity and enhance your verbal and written communication skills, essential for engaging with employers, clients, and stakeholders. You will have the opportunity to craft a professional identity, crucial for employment and meeting Engineers Australia's mandate of at least 12 weeks of professional practice. You'll compile a professional practice portfolio showcasing your learning and reflecting on your experiences, culminating in an interview discussing your professional journey and portfolio contents.

title: Professional Practice in Computing
description: This subject focuses on tools and techniques used in the professional practice of design, implementation, cybersecurity, and maintenance of computing systems and related software systems. You will gain an understanding of professional standards, codes of conduct, and methodologies for ensuring high quality outcomes in the various domains within which computing systems are employed and how to convey professional progression in these areas.

title: Professional Practice Preparation 2
description: This subject prepares you for an engineering career by aligning with Engineers Australia Stage 2 Competency Standards. Through participation in five workshops, you'll gain insights into employment processes, ethics, social responsibility, and leadership, while honing creativity and understanding workplace culture. You'll develop communication skills and readiness for senior internships by engaging in collaborative tasks and reflective practices. Pre-workshop readings enable you to contribute effectively to discussions, equipping you for professional hurdles and continuous learning.

title: Professional Practice Review 1
description: This subject equips you with critical reflection and presentation skills, enhancing your professional development. You'll learn to write critical incidents, conduct constructive reviews, and deliver concise online presentations. Your learning journey combines recorded lectures, interactive tutorials, and seminars, fostering both independent study and collaborative engagement. Prior to sessions, you'll engage with online resources and submit reflective entries, which serve as a foundation for peer feedback in tutorials. This process not only refines your reflective writing but also aids in articulating your professional identity. You'll summarise peer feedback for assessment and later, present a three-slide narrative of your internship experience, encapsulating your growth and lessons learned.

title: Professional Practice Review 2
description: This subject allows you to reflect on and articulate your workplace learning, preparing you for a graduate engineering role, chartered status, or to contribute to the field. Through four interactive workshops and a Professional Practice & Leadership Forum, you'll present your work to industry experts. You'll also form a Peer Review Group for collaborative learning. Attendance at the forum is mandatory, though special consideration may be available if you're unable to present.

title: Professional Practice Studio
description: The Professional Practice Studio is an interdisciplinary space where students from engineering and IT collaborate on complex, real-world problems alongside industry and community partners. This subject challenges your perceptions of your studies, career, and professional identity. You'll apply engineering and IT skills to unconventional problems, demonstrating the versatility of these disciplines. The studio enhances research, design thinking, and systems thinking skills, while offering networking opportunities with professionals and academics. You'll gain a portfolio-worthy project, learn to articulate your practice to employers, and understand the application of academic learning in professional settings. The studio combines workshops and independent work, transitioning from staff-led to student-directed as you progress. For more details and to prepare for enrolment, visit the UTS Professional Practice Studio website.

title: Professional Service Project A
description: This subject enhances your understanding of the societal, economic, and environmental impact of engineering and IT professions through active engagement in professional services. You'll collaborate with non-engineering professionals, broadening your interdisciplinary awareness and group management skills. By reflecting on professional behaviours, you'll identify and develop the competencies essential for a graduate engineer or IT professional. Your service experiences will inform the development of skills, with learning activities and assessments tailored through discussions with a supervisor.

title: Professional Service Project B
description: This suite of subjects develops an appreciation of the service obligations and non-financial rewards associated with the award of professional status. Students participate in one or more professional service activities and thus build their understanding of the culture of engineering and the current debates surrounding it.Students are required to analyse the impact of the activity on the recipient organisation and to evaluate the competence they need to be able to perform the service in a manner consistent with the Code of Ethics. In many cases, students work with professionals from non-engineering disciplines. This increases their awareness of engineers' interdependence on other professions as well as enhancing their experience in managing group dynamics.Students gain an understanding of the role engineering plays in society and in particular the perception that the community at large has about engineering.Students are able to volunteer for professional service projects throughout their course for which they receive a certificate.

title: Professional Studio A
description: In this first professional studio, you'll bridge theory and practice within a studio setting, translating knowledge into tangible capabilities. You'll collaborate with others, including industry and research product owners, to undertake project work that embodies the full engineering process: assess, design, and implement, all aligned with a learning contract. The Professional Studio emphasises your evolution into a professional engineer, reflected in product development choices that may range from industry-aligned to research-driven or entrepreneurial ventures. You'll incorporate industry standards and best practices, encompassing the entire product lifecycle from stakeholder analysis to validation and pitching. Beyond technical specifications, you're encouraged to consider commercialisation, intellectual property, ethics, equity, privacy and security aspects relevant to your product, preparing you for the multifaceted role of a professional engineer.

title: Professional Studio B
description: In this second professional studio, you'll further develop the ability to turn knowledge into action in a studio environment. Collaborative and individual work, guided by a learning contract, will see you progress through the engineering phases of assessment, design, and implementation. This studio sharpens your focus on the professional engineering role within product development, allowing for industry, research, or entrepreneurial projects. You'll be expected to adhere to industry standards and best practices, managing the full product lifecycle from needs analysis to final validation and pitching. Critical thinking extends beyond technical achievements, encompassing commercial, ethical, and legal considerations, ensuring a comprehensive approach to your engineering practice.

title: Programming 1
description: This subject provides a foundation in core programming concepts, vital for careers in computer science and software development. It emphasises project-based learning, independent research, and effective communication. You'll also be introduced to real-world programming practices, preparing you to tackle complex industry-level projects. This approach ensures you develop the multifaceted skill set required for solving sophisticated programming challenges.

title: Programming 2
description: This subject teaches concepts, theories and technologies underlying the methods and techniques of OOP programming and GUI programming. You will learn through a combination of lectures, assignments, and practical labs designed to solve real-world problems using Java or Python. The subject will enable you to design, develop and evaluate software systems to meet predefined quality characteristics of functionality (suitability) and usability (understandability, learnability, operability, compliance). By gaining both theoretical understanding and practical skills, you will be equipped to apply all that you have learned to develop and implement the architecture of a business system in various domains.

title: Programming for Mechatronic Systems
description: This subject lays out the theoretical foundations of object-oriented programming using C++, honing your skills in designing, implementing and managing code for moderately complex mechatronics systems. You'll learn to create modular, reusable, reliable, and maintainable code. Through an individual project, you'll apply these concepts to design and implement components of a mechatronic system, tackling real-life challenges. The curriculum covers objects, classes, abstraction, inheritance, polymorphism, threading, event handling, and the use of C++ standard features like the STL, APIs, middleware, as well as documentation and testing strategies.

title: Programming Fundamentals
description: This subject teaches introductory-level Java programming and software design, with no assumed prior knowledge of programming. You will learn about object-oriented programming concepts, data flow, control flow, and basic data structures.

title: Programming on the Internet
description: This subject introduces web and internet-based programming, covering the internet's evolution and its technical underpinnings, as well as data presentation techniques. You'll focus on PHP, MySQL, JavaScript, AJAX, XML, and Object-Oriented PHP, providing a solid understanding of web functionality, website construction, and advanced scripting for the web.

title: Project BEngSc
description: This project subject allows you to apply your accumulated knowledge in a multidisciplinary engineering project, working within a team to cover the full design cycle and project management methodologies. You'll engage with clients to define requirements, develop specifications, and evaluate alternative solutions. The experience hones your ability to articulate needs and assess engineering responses. You'll document the process and outcomes in a detailed report and present your project through diverse communication channels, both online and in person.

title: Project Management and the Professional
description:
This subject equips you with project management skills, focusing on information systems and professional project management. You will learn about ethical standards and the organisational context of projects. You will also learn about the roles of project team members,  managing time, risk, cost and communications and the value of quality. These skills are vital for university success and for success in your future career.  

Learning involves being part of a small project team. You will collaborate to create project documents, receiving constructive feedback to foster improvement. These activities culminate in a significant group assessment followed by a reflection on what you have learnt.  
 
You will also write a report stating the possible ethical dilemmas in a given case study and describing how industry codes may be used to suggest solutions to these dilemmas. Academic and professional language and communication skills are measured through a milestone assessment task that gauges both your subject knowledge and communication proficiency.

title: Project Management and the Professional
description: This subject equips you with project management skills, focusing on information systems and professional project management. You will learn about ethical standards and the organisational context of projects. You will also learn about the roles of project team members, managing time, risk, cost and communications and the value of quality. These skills are vital for university success and for success in your future career. Learning involves being part of a small project team. You will collaborate to create project documents, receiving constructive feedback to foster improvement. These activities culminate in a significant group assessment followed by a reflection on what you have learnt. You will also write a report stating the possible ethical dilemmas in a given case study and describing how industry codes may be used to suggest solutions to these dilemmas. Academic and professional language and communication skills are measured through a milestone assessment task that gauges both your subject knowledge and communication proficiency.

title: Prototyping Physical Interaction
description: This subject hones your ability to design, assess, and implement interactive physical devices with a human-centred approach. You'll learn to prototype using sensors, actuators, and diverse display methods to enhance user interaction and experience. By processing sensor data and designing multimodal feedback, you'll refine your prototypes through iterative user assessments, progressively perfecting the design.

title: Quantum Algorithms
description: You'll gain proficiency in fundamental quantum algorithms, such as Shor's algorithm for integer factorisation and Grover's search algorithm. From there, you’ll learn about quantum walks, simulation of quantum systems, and algorithms for solving linear equations.

title: Quantum Computer Architectures
description: This subject delves into quantum computing, where quantum processors confer exponential advantages over classical counterparts. Quantum architecture design is an interdisciplinary field, combining physics, information theory, computer science, and control theory. You'll learn the workings of quantum processors, explore varied construction approaches, and master control and characterization techniques, gaining a comprehensive understanding of quantum computing architectures.

title: Quantum Information Theory
description: This subject enhances your understanding of Quantum Information Theory, the mathematical backbone of quantum computing and information science. You'll grasp key concepts such as entropy, entanglement, and the uncertainty principle, and their applications in secure communication and the potential quantum internet. Additionally, you'll master advanced mathematical techniques essential across all quantum information theory domains.

title: Quantum Software and Programming
description: This subject introduces you to the quantum technology ecosystem through hands-on use of emerging quantum software tools. You'll solidify your understanding of quantum computing by learning to analyse quantum circuits, investigating how they can be used to solve problems, and creating simulations of those quantum circuits.

title: Real-time Operating Systems
description: This subject provides an understanding of computer operating systems for embedded systems, PCs, and servers. It focuses on their roles in a conventional computing environment and addresses how operating systems support real-time computing requirements, such as managing operating for programming on PC and server. You'll explore process management, scheduling, inter-process communication, memory, and I/O device management through case studies on OS adaptations. Practical work includes programming in POSIX-compliant C, using the Linux kernel as a UNIX example, and studying real-time systems, real-time kernels, and CPU scheduling.

title: Realtime Animation
description: This subject guides you through the development and execution of real-time animation projects using industry-standard game engines and tools. Real-time animation, notably in 3D game engines, extends beyond games and film to sectors like architecture, fashion, manufacturing, and health sciences. You'll create animations, craft digital assets, and master processes including modelling, rigging, motion capture, and post-production, equipping you with versatile skills applicable across various industries.

title: Renewable Energy Systems Studio A
description: Power electronics is a crucial technology that enables the efficient management and conversion of electrical power in various applications, including motor drives, renewable energy systems, data centers, and HVDC networks. This studio provides an engaging learning experience, equipping you with the skills to understand and control power electronic converters, particularly in renewable energy contexts such as solar PV-battery systems. Throughout this subject, you will explore the details of circuitry and control challenges inherent in power electronic systems. You will gain practical experience using commercial software for thorough circuit analysis and development, allowing you to design circuits that meet industry standards and custom specifications. By the end of the studio, you will have the knowledge to create basic power electronic circuits tailored for renewable energy applications, preparing you for a career in this dynamic and essential field.

title: Renewable Energy Systems Studio B
description: This studio introduces you to modern renewable energy technologies, encompassing sustainability, environmental impact, and various energy sources such as solar, wind, fuel cell, and hydro. You'll explore energy storage, system integration, and applications like microgrids.
