In-depth discussions on design techniques for renewable energy systems prepare you for a group project, where you'll engage in system specification, options analysis, and design implementation. The subject aims to equip you with the knowledge and skills to design a renewable energy system effectively.

title: Road and Transport Engineering
description: This introductory subject explores transport engineering within civil and environmental engineering, emphasising sustainable design and planning. It encompasses transport planning, focusing on public transport systems analysis, design, and evaluation. In addition, you’ll learn the basics of traffic engineering, where you will develop a '4-step transport model' to assess regional travel demands, crucial for infrastructure feasibility and design. You'll also grasp traffic flow theory fundamentals, enabling you to evaluate transport capacity and infrastructure. Practical case studies, including local area traffic management schemes, illustrate applications of theory, equipping you with relevant assessment tools and skills to be a transport professional.

title: Robotics Studio 1
description: This studio develops your skills in critiquing and designing modern estimation methods for robotics and mechatronic systems. You will dissect a mechatronics problem, discerning the requirements for an estimation solution and applying suitable techniques. Your analysis will assess the design's suitability and justify the choices made, deepening your understanding of the capabilities and limitations of these engineering tools in system design.

title: Robotics Studio 2
description: Building upon previous studios and technical subjects, this studio engages you in interpreting a broadly defined robotics challenge, to be addressed with robot path-planning or control techniques. You will work in teams to devise a unique design solution using systems engineering principles, bridging engineering and professional practice. This subject blends technical design work with elements from systems engineering, requiring you to scope out a project, do the technical developments, plan and execute tests, and integrate multiple subsystems together as a team.

title: Routing and Switching Essentials
description: Building on prior knowledge, this subject offers a deeper dive into networking. You'll develop expertise for specialisation and understand networks' influence on applications. Key skills include learning IP addressing, routing protocols and switched networks. You will be designing and implementing small to medium-sized intranets, and managing network security. You'll also evaluate the role of TCP/IP, ICMP, and other IP network protocols, with practical work involving CISCO routers and switches.

title: Secure Programming and Penetration Testing
description: This subject will equip you with the knowledge and skills necessary to develop secure software and assess the security of systems through source code analysis and penetration testing techniques. There will be coverage of the principles and practices of secure coding, the identification and mitigation of vulnerabilities, software verification, and the methodologies used in penetration testing. You will learn how to approach and develop automatic auditing systems, identifying vulnerabilities and developing security analysis and testing methods to protect systems against cyber-attacks. Additionally, you'll have the chance to engage in national and international security challenges, with assessments on secure programming, software analysis, and your communication skills in speaking and writing.

title: Sensors and Control for Mechatronic Systems
description: This subject aims to enhance your theoretical knowledge and practical skills in both active and passive sensing, as well as feedback control techniques for mechatronic and robotic systems. You'll learn to select and evaluate sensors, process sensor data, and implement computer-aided tools for designing control systems that leverage sensory information. Key topics include visual and infrared imaging, time of flight measurements, detection, tracking, state-space modelling, stability, controllability, observability, and advanced control strategies like linear quadratic control and nonlinear system control, . Real-world engineering case studies will contextualise and examine these concepts.

title: Serious Games and Gamification Studio
description: This subject focuses on creating serious games and gamified experiences, designed for purposes beyond entertainment such as education or training. You'll learn cutting-edge design frameworks and techniques for tailoring games to specific audiences and objectives. Working with end-users, you'll engage in co-design workshops, prototype development, playtesting, and evaluation to ensure impactful outcomes. Additionally, you'll consider the ethical implications inherent in game design.

title: Signals and Systems
description: This subject lays the theoretical groundwork for system analysis and equips you with skills for designing components within control and communication systems. You will learn to derive models from actual devices, compare predictions with experimental outcomes, and apply your knowledge through a group project focused on a real-world control or communication challenge. Core topics include signal representation, system modelling with equations and transforms, signal processing, the interplay between discrete and continuous data, feedback effects, system performance, stability, and control design principles. Through various learning activities, you will also improve your academic literacy and gain insight into engineering's diverse practice areas. The subject incorporates lectures, tutorials, lab work, and project assignments. Lab sessions, integrated with MATLAB simulations, reinforce theoretical concepts and allow you to engage with practical applications directly.

title: Software Analysis Studio
description: This subject introduces you to automated software analysis to detect software bugs and enhance system reliability and security. You will apply system programming skills based on open-source frameworks to design and develop source code analysis tools for identifying coding errors. You will engage with real-world software development practices in this subject. Assessment will be based on your technical capabilities, comprehension of software analysis and communication abilities.

title: Software Architecture
description: This subject covers essential concepts, methodologies, and practical skills for designing, developing, and assessing software architectures. You will gain hands-on experience with architectural tools, techniques, and real-world scenarios. This subject prepares you to tackle complex software architecture challenges and make informed architectural decisions in your professional career. You will apply the industry practices to architect a business system, ensuring it aligns with professional standards.

title: Software Defined Networks
description: This subject addresses the demand for skilled network engineers in Software Defined Networking (SDN), a framework poised to meet the scalability and extensibility challenges of modern telecommunication networks. You will learn key SDN concepts and Network Function Virtualisation (NFV), and through hands-on labs, you will develop applications over an SDN controller. The subject equips you with the skills to enhance performance in data centres and enterprise networks, preparing you for industry needs.

title: Software Design Studio
description: This subject equips you with the experience and understanding of software engineering practices necessary for developing large, fail-safe systems. You'll learn the importance of balancing initial design with solution implementation, and through hands-on experience, appreciate the need for discipline in maintaining robust practices. The subject emphasises understanding the long-term impact of chosen development methods, tools, and resources, and fosters the ability to critically evaluate and enhance these processes.

title: Software Development Studio
description: This studio subject focuses on the practical aspects of software development, fostering a rich and engaging practice-based environment to enhance your professional competence. It emphasises reflective design, teamwork, mentoring, and learning through tackling challenging problems. You will form teams with your peers to simulate a real software development team, interacting with industry or academic clients to understand their requirements and deliver software solutions. Teaching is delivered through mini-lectures in studio sessions, covering topics such as version control and agile project management. In the assessments, you will demonstrate your software design and development skills, as well as your skill in reflective practice. By completing this subject, you will be equipped with knowledge and experience that is in high demand in industry.

title: Software Innovation Studio
description: The Software Innovation Studio subject blends field research and user observation with cutting-edge algorithm application to drive innovation in software design and service enhancement. It cultivates skills in idea generation, logical reasoning, systematic execution, and agile project management. You'll experience the full software engineering cycle in a practice- and project-based setting, with the goal of developing valuable software solutions, enhancing existing platforms, or resolving complex issues.

title: Soil Behaviour
description: This subject provides a comprehensive introduction to geosciences and a detailed understanding of soil as an engineering material, culminating in studies of soil settlement and shear strength. Through practical geology and soil laboratory sessions, you'll gain hands-on experience and insights into soil behaviour from a civil/geotechnical engineering perspective. By the end of the subject, you'll be conversant with earth surface processes, able to communicate with geotechnical professionals, comprehend soil behaviour, recognise soil's environmental impact, and solve soil-related problems, particularly those involving water flow and settlement. This foundation prepares you for advanced geotechnical studies and self-learning.

title: Steel and Timber Design Studio
description:
This Pre-Professional design studio introduces you to practical techniques in design of steel and timber structures. The emphasis is on analysis and design of structural members and connections of steel and timber structures, computer-aided structural design and design optimisation techniques, and producing construction sketches for the main structural components of buildings. This subject is based on authentic professional projects relevant to the building industry that you may wish to enter, providing material for a portfolio after graduation. You will work with a wide range of data inputs to apply innovative and thoughtful opportunities to learn critical review of engineering documents/projects and disciplinary research skills.
This Steel and Timber Design Studio enables you to demonstrate achievement of professional skills by working on real-world projects. Facilitated by a mixture of studio facilitators, academic experts, and industry partners, you will work in teams to define problems, and identify, develop, and implement solutions. Using a design-thinking framework and systems thinking, you will regularly engage in pitching and critiquing work among peers. In the assessments, you are required to demonstrate your achievement of each of the subject learning objectives using a collection of artefacts and reflections that meet the standard performance criteria for each grade.

title: Strategic IT Project
description: This subject equips you with strategic analysis and design skills for the  corporate information systems environment, culminating in a comprehensive case study solution that hones your judgement and application of knowledge. You'll learn to evaluate system strategies and enhance your senior management and communication abilities. Learning unfolds through initial briefings, followed by weekly collaborative tutorials where you receive direct feedback to refine your approach. You'll use the skill sets developed through your course of studies as well as essential resources on  Canvas to coordinate group activities, with online content supporting your teamwork. Emphasis is placed on using collaborative technologies to advance your project outside of formal meetings, fostering a practical, team-oriented industry-like experience.

title: Structural Analysis
description: This subject teaches you to apply classical structural theory to analyse load-bearing structures and their components. You'll learn to assess the response of linear elastic structures to mechanical loads and environmental effects, including temperature changes and foundation settlements. Additionally, you'll learn to predict structural behaviour, determine deformed shapes, support reactions, and internal force distributions. These concepts are foundational for advanced subjects in structural design, including Concrete Design and Steel and Timber Design.

title: Surveying
description: This subject equips students with essential surveying skills, both theoretical and practical, including the use of levels and theodolites. You'll learn to perform calculations, reduce observations, and understand potential errors and their mitigation associated with the equipment. This foundational subject covers accurate distance measurement with tapes and introduces electronic distance measuring tools. You'll conduct simple traverse and perform associated calculations for engineering applications of surveying and engage with the stadia method in practical exercises. The plotting and application of contour plans for road design, as well as vertical and horizontal alignments, are also introduced. Additionally, you'll gain a basic understanding of Geographic Information Systems (GIS), including its components and spatial data analysis. Modern surveying developments and equipment are discussed, with a strong emphasis on professional surveying and engineering practices throughout the subject.

title: Sustainable Energy Studio
description: This studio challenges students to reimagine the world's energy systems with sustainability and resilience at the core. You will explore avenues such as optimizing fossil fuel technology to mitigate its impact, scaling the deployment of renewable energy for a sustainable energy transition, and advancing energy efficiency in generation, transmission, and use. You'll examine current systems and sustainability issues, gaining a foundational understanding of development principles related to both renewable and non-renewable sources. Additionally, you'll assess the social, environmental, and economic facets of decarbonizing emissions and the potential for a carbon-free energy future, considering the effects on communities worldwide.

title: System Security
description: This subject provides a comprehensive understanding of contemporary system security concepts, strategies, and practical techniques essential for securing operating systems, databases, and servers. You will learn to implement security measures throughout the design and configuration phases, ensuring robust system security and privacy. The subject places a strong emphasis on system hardening mechanisms and prominent security techniques, which you will apply in hands-on practical sessions. By testing the resilience of hardened systems against various attack vectors, you will gain critical skills in defending against real-world cybersecurity threats. This subject fosters both theoretical knowledge and practical expertise, preparing you to effectively safeguard corporate computing environments.

title: Systems Testing and Quality Management
description: This subject equips you with practical knowledge and skills for measuring and controlling software quality. You'll learn about software quality assurance, management principles, and testing approaches for systems and software.

title: Technical Direction for 3D Animation and Graphics Projects
description: This subject prepares you to excel as a Technical Director in computer graphics, encompassing 3D animation, visualisation, VFX, and games production. Technical Directors craft tools, maintain software, and manage the production pipeline. They work in animation and visual effects studios and in the games industry.  You'll need robust coding skills and a fundamental knowledge of Python.

title: Theory of Computing Science
description: This subject explores the theory of computation, covering automata, decidability, and computational complexity. These topics provide key tools for you to perform rewriting and parsing, and to determine the complexity of various problems. Understanding computational complexity is crucial for creating cost-effective and practical solutions, such as optimising large-scale problems in online services. Additionally, a firm grasp of computational theory underpins the creation of user-friendly, secure systems and the identification of performance issues in programming, leading to more efficient algorithm design.

title: Thermofluids A
description: This subject imparts an understanding of fluids and heat transfer, which are integral to machine design and operation. You'll grasp key concepts and principles, enabling practical analysis and design of engineering systems. The curriculum fosters an interest in fluid and thermal phenomena, covering applications from basic to complex.

title: Unit Operations
description:
In this Developing subject, you will exercise your knowledge and skills to design and operate unit operations and equipment for chemical process engineering applications, e.g., oil & gas refining, pharmaceuticals, food & beverage, and water purification, safely and economically. You will learn the principles of membrane separation, distillation, liquid-liquid extraction, ion exchange, absorption, adsorption, and drying in industrial processes, as well as learning to incorporate economics, safety, and environmental sustainability in all stages of the design.
 
By the end of this subject, you will be able to analyse the transport phenomena of the fluids as well as various separation processes. Furthermore, you will develop skills to design and formulate the piping and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) of an integrated system of multiple unit operations, and provide justification/assessment of the P&ID based on hazard and operability study, safety life cycle and techno-economic analysis. You will also gain the ability to critically evaluate process designs using hazard identification techniques, assess operability for safe and efficient operation, and perform techno-economic analyses to ensure project feasibility, equipping you to make informed decisions about the process design lifecycle, safety, operability, and economic viability.

title: Water and Environmental Design Studio
description: This pre-professional studio provides you with the opportunity to address complex engineering challenges in water and land management, considering cultural and environmental factors. You will develop skills in assessing cultural sensitivities, exploring engineering options, and understanding the uncertainties influencing project outcomes. The focus is on practical applications, mirroring industry practices throughout the project lifecycle, including planning, management, and stakeholder engagement. You will work collaboratively and receive continuous feedback to develop a comprehensive understanding of project development.

title: Water Supply and Wastewater Engineering
description: This subject equips civil and environmental engineering students with comprehensive knowledge of water pollution control, potable water and sewage treatment process design, sewerage and water distribution systems, and advanced technologies for enhancing water and wastewater treatment, including desalination and re-use. By the end of the subject, you will be capable of designing water supply and waste disposal systems that safeguard public health and the environment, calculating reactor sizes for treatment plants, and addressing water quality and re-use objectives.

title: Web Systems
description: This subject is an introduction to information technology, using the web as a core case study. You will learn about the underlying hardware, software, networks and operating systems behind websites, and set up a functional website using this knowledge.

title: Work Integrated Learning (BIT)
description: In this professional placement subject you will use feedback and self-reflection to enhance your knowledge and self-awareness of roles and behaviors in a professional environment, thereby developing your capacity for personal reflection and furthering your understanding of a specific professional organisation. You will also have the opportunity to enhance your academic skills, by doing a mini-academic, scholarly literature review on the problem context related to your work experience.

title: Work Integrated Learning 1
description: This subject complements your internship, focusing on enhancing your professional growth through reflection and documentation of your engineering experiences. You'll develop key skills in self-assessment, reflection, goal setting, and documenting professional capabilities. Your work will be valuable for subsequent subjects, particularly in creating performance appraisals and reflective journals. Learning involves active engagement with your experiences, fostering a deeper understanding and proficiency in engineering practices.

title: Work Integrated Learning 2
description: This subject equips you with a broader understanding of professional practice, complementing your internship experiences. You'll develop key skills and knowledge, gaining insights beyond the scope of your host organisation. Learning is online, offering flexibility as you intern anywhere, and includes a mandatory module plus an elective of your choice on Canvas. This approach ensures a well-rounded professional development journey.

title: Work Integrated Learning Capstone
description: This subject serves as a capstone, synthesising your course knowledge and skills by applying them to a complex, real-world problem. It encourages extending your current abilities and developing new competencies through a professionally executed project. The project is a stepping stone to your professional career, showcasing your initiative, creativity, and professional competencies. As IT is diverse and work experiences vary, formal training by employers is not mandatory. You are expected to proactively engage in learning, setting goals with an academic supervisor, and demonstrating skill acquisition through evidence. While most projects are goal-oriented, some may integrate learning within ongoing workplace activities.
